justification.D: In the event of an investigation, the device may be seized by law enforcement, but it is not expected that security will have the authority to seize the device. Varying standards of privacy and other forms of legal protection around the world make it difficult to apply common standards to private seizure of personal devices even if an internal investigation may be warranted.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important process that an information security manager needs to negotiate with an outsourced service provider?

options.A: The right to conduct independent security reviews
options.B: A legally binding data protection agreement
options.C: Encryption between the enterprise and the provider
options.D: A joint risk assessment of the system

justification.A: A key requirement of an outsourced contract involving critical business systems is the establishment of the enterprise's right to conduct independent security reviews of the provider's security controls.
justification.B: A legally binding data protection agreement is also critical but secondary to conducting independent security reviews that permit examination of the actual security controls prevailing over the system, which is a more effective risk management tool.
justification.C: Network encryption of the link between the enterprise and the provider may well be a requirement but by itself will not provide the assurance of independent security reviews.
justification.D: A joint risk assessment of the system in conjunction with the outsourced provider may be a compromise solution should the right to conduct independent security reviews of the controls related to the system prove contractually difficult, but it is not the best option.

question: Which resource is the MOST effective in preventing physical access tailgating/piggybacking?

justification.A: Card key door locks are a physical control that by itself would not be effective against tailgating.
justification.B: Photo identification by itself would not be effective against tailgating.
justification.C: Awareness training would most likely result in any attempted tailgating being challenged by the authorized employee.
justification.D: A biometric scanner is a physical control that by itself would not be effective against tailgating.

question: What is the BEST approach to implement adequate segregation of duties in business-critical applications if shared access to elevated privileges by a small group is necessary?

options.A: Ensure access to individual functions can be granted to individual users only.
options.B: Implement role-based access control in the application.
options.C: Enforce manual procedures ensuring separation of conflicting duties.
options.D: Create service accounts that can only be used by authorized team members.

justification.A: Access to individual functions will not ensure appropriate segregation of duties (SoD).
justification.B: Role-based access control is the best way to implement appropriate SoD. Roles will have to be defined once, and then the user can be changed from one role to another without redefining the content of the role each time.
justification.C: Giving a user access to all functions and implementing, in parallel, a manual procedure ensuring SoD is not an effective method, and it would be difficult to enforce and monitor.
justification.D: Creating service accounts that can be used by authorized team members would not provide any help unless their roles were properly segregated.

question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY driver for initial implementation of a risk-based information security program?

justification.A: Because enterprises rarely have adequate resources to address all concerns, a risk-based information security program is typically implemented to provide a basis for efficient allocation of limited resources.
justification.B: Motivation is useful in getting the job done but is not necessarily a result of implementing a risk-based information security program.
justification.C: Optimization is a long-term benefit associated with a mature risk-based program. It does not present itself during initial implementation.
justification.D: Standardization is a technique that offers numerous benefits and may support risk management activities. It is not the result of a focus on risk.

question: What is the MOST critical success factor of the patch management procedure in an enterprise where availability is a primary concern?

options.A: Testing time window prior to deployment
options.B: Technical skills of the team responsible
options.D: Automated deployment to all the servers

justification.A: Having the patch tested prior to implementation on critical systems is an absolute prerequisite if availability is a primary concern because deploying patches that could cause a system to fail could be worse than the vulnerability corrected by the patch.
justification.B: A high level of technical skills is not required because patches are usually applied via automated tools.
justification.C: Validation of the patch is essential but is unrelated to the testing, which is the primary area of concern.
justification.D: It makes no sense to deploy patches on every system. Vulnerable systems should be the only candidates for patching.

question: Who should be involved in the design of information security procedures to ensure they are functional and accurate?

justification.A: End users are normally not involved in procedure development other than testing.
justification.B: Legal counsel is normally not involved in procedure development.
justification.C: Procedures at the operational level must be developed by or with the involvement of operational units that will use them. This will ensure that they are functional and accurate.
justification.D: Audit management generally oversees information security operations but does not get involved at the procedural level.

question: An information security manager reviewed the access control lists and observed that privileged access was granted to an entire department. Which of the following should the information security manager do FIRST?

options.A: Review the procedures for granting access.
options.B: Establish procedures for granting emergency access.
options.C: Meet with data owners to understand business needs.
options.D: Redefine and implement proper access rights.

justification.A: Reviewing the procedures for granting access could be correct depending on the priorities set by the business unit, but this would follow understanding the business needs.
justification.B: Procedures for granting emergency access require first understanding business needs.
justification.C: An information security manager must understand the business needs that motivated the change prior to taking any unilateral action.
justification.D: Redefining and implementing proper access rights would follow understanding the business needs.

question: Which of the following should be in place before a black box penetration test begins?

options.C: A clearly stated definition of scope

justification.A: IT management approval may not be required, based on senior management decisions.
justification.B: Communication, awareness and an incident response plan are not a necessary requirement.
justification.C: Having a clearly stated definition of scope is most important to ensure a proper understanding of risk and success criteria.
justification.D: A penetration test could help promote the creation and execution of the incident response plan.

question: For which of the following types of controls is notification of a verified network intrusion an indication that the control is working properly?

justification.A: Preventative controls, such as authentication mechanisms and encryption, are intended to stop intrusions, so a verified intrusion indicates that preventative controls were ineffective.
justification.B: Corrective controls, such as backups and failover capabilities, are intended to offset the impact caused by successful attacks directed against information systems. Intrusions may not have impact at the time of their detection, so an intrusion does not unto itself offer any indications regarding the workings of corrective controls.
justification.C: Detective controls, such as intrusion detection systems, are designed to alert staff to intrusions when they occur. Notification of a verified network intrusion is an indication that the control is working properly.
justification.D: Deterrent controls, such as warning banners, are intended to reduce the threat level by creating disincentives for threat events. A verified network intrusion indicates that the deterrent was inadequate for the responsible threat actor.

question: The MOST effective way to limit actual and potential impacts of e-discovery in the event of litigation is to:

options.A: implement strong encryption of all sensitive documentation.
options.B: ensure segregation of duties and limited access to sensitive data.
options.C: enforce a policy of not writing or storing potentially sensitive information.
options.D: develop and enforce comprehensive retention policies.

justification.A: Encryption will not prevent the legal requirements to produce documents in the event of legal conflicts.
justification.B: Limiting access to sensitive information based on the need to know may limit which personnel can testify during legal proceedings but will not limit the requirement to produce existing documents.
justification.C: While some enterprises have practiced a policy of not committing to writing issues of dubious legality, it is not a sound practice and may violate a variety of laws.
justification.D: Compliance with legally acceptable defined retention policies will limit exposure to the often difficult and costly demands for documentation during legal proceedings such as lawsuits.

question: Which of the following BEST protects confidentiality of information?

justification.A: While classifying information can help focus the assignment of privileges, classification itself does not provide enforcement.
justification.B: Only in very specific situations does segregation of duties safeguard confidentiality of information.
justification.C: Restricting access to information to those who need to have access is the most effective means of protecting confidentiality.
justification.D: Systems monitoring is a detective control rather than a preventive control.

question: Who should determine the appropriate classification of accounting ledger data located on a database server and maintained by a database administrator in the IT department?

justification.A: The database administrator is the custodian of the data who would apply the appropriate security levels for the classification.
justification.B: Data owners are responsible for determining data classification; in this case, management of the finance department would be the owner of accounting ledger data.
justification.C: The security manager would act as an advisor and enforcer.
justification.D: The IT management is the custodian of the data who would apply the appropriate security levels for the classification.

question: A company uses a single employee to update the servers, review the audit logs and maintain access controls. Which of the following choices is the BEST compensating control?

options.A: Verify that only approved changes are made.
options.D: Implement supervisor review of log files.

justification.A: Where segregation of duties is not possible, additional procedures are needed to ensure that a single person with access is not able to abuse that access.
justification.B: Penetration tests do not address insider threat.
justification.C: Vulnerability scans only check hardware and software for changes against set requirements. There is no correlation to unauthorized activities.
justification.D: A sufficiently knowledgeable administrator may be able to manipulate the log files and hide their activities from the supervisor.

question: Which of the following steps should be FIRST in developing an information security plan?

options.D: Assess the current levels of security awareness.

justification.A: Technical vulnerabilities as a component of risk will be most relevant in the context of threats to achieving the business objectives defined in the business strategy.
justification.B: An information security manager needs to first gain an understanding of the current business strategy and direction to understand the enterprise's objectives and the impact of the other answers on achieving those objectives.
justification.C: A business impact analysis should be performed prior to developing a business continuity plan, but this would not be an appropriate first step in developing an information security plan because it focuses on impact due to non-availability, which is also primarily relevant in terms of the business objectives that are the basis of the strategy.
justification.D: Assessment of the current level of awareness is not the appropriate first step in developing an information security plan because awareness is a component of the plan itself.

question: Determining which element of the confidentiality, integrity and availability (CIA) triad is MOST important is a necessary task when:

justification.A: Overall risk is not affected by determining which element of the triad is of the greatest importance because overall risk is constructed from all known risk, regardless of the components of the triad to which each risk applies.
justification.B: Because preventive controls necessarily must fail in either an open or closed state (i.e., fail safe or fail secure), and failing open favors availability while failing closed favors confidentiality—each at the expense of the other—a clear prioritization of the triad components is needed to develop a controls policy.
justification.C: Although it is feasible that establishing a control that bolsters one component of the triad may diminish another, treatment options may be determined without a clear prioritization of the triad.
justification.D: Classification is based on the potential impact of compromise and is not a function of prioritization within the confidentiality, integrity and availability (CIA) triad.

question: Which of the following attributes would be MOST essential to developing effective metrics?

justification.A: Ease of implementation is valuable when developing metrics, but not essential. Metrics are most effective when they are meaningful to the person receiving the information.
justification.B: Metrics will only be effective if the recipient can take appropriate action based upon the results, in other words—the metrics have to be meaningful to the recipient and provide business value.
justification.C: Quantifiable representations can be useful, but qualitative measures are often just as useful.
justification.D: Meeting legal and regulatory requirements may be important, but this is not always essential when developing metrics for meeting business goals.

question: The effectiveness of segregation of duties may be MOST seriously compromised when:

options.A: user IDs of terminated staff remain active in application systems.
options.B: access privileges are accumulated based on previous job functions.
options.C: application role-based access deviates from the organizational hierarchies.
options.D: role mining tools are used in the access privilege review.

justification.A: It is not desirable to leave user IDs of terminated personnel or contractors active in the systems because it increases the potential for unauthorized access. However, the risk related to not effectively managing terminated users is an access management issue, not a segregation of duties issue.
justification.B: When the changing of user roles is not adequately managed, access privileges may cross the boundary of segregation of duties. This often happens when a user's role changes as part of a promotion or transfer, and the user is assigned new system privileges to fulfill the new role but the privileges of the previous role are not removed.
justification.C: Role-based access is built on the premise that users are granted those privileges that they need to perform their daily job functions (roles). These do not necessarily need to be aligned with the organizational hierarchies.
justification.D: Using role mining tools in the access entitlement review may enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of the process, particularly in large and complex environments.

question: Which of the following BEST mitigates a situation in which an application programmer requires access to production data?

options.A: Create a separate account for the programmer as a power user.
options.B: Log all the programmers' activity for review by supervisor.
options.C: Have the programmer sign a letter accepting full responsibility.
options.D: Perform regular audits of the application.

justification.A: Creating a separate account for the programmer as a power user does not solve the problem.
justification.B: It is not always possible to provide adequate segregation of duties between programming and operations in order to meet certain business requirements. A mitigating control is to record all the programmers' actions for later review by their supervisor, which would detect any inappropriate action on the part of the programmer.
justification.C: Having the programmer sign a letter accepting full responsibility is not an effective control.
justification.D: Performing regular audits of the application is not relevant to determine if programmer activities are appropriate.

question: What action should be taken concerning data classification requirements before engaging outsourced providers?

options.A: are compatible with the provider's own classification.

justification.A: Ensuring the data classification requirements are compatible with the provider's own classification is an acceptable option but does not provide a requirement for the handling of classified data.
justification.B: Ensuring the data classification requirements are communicated to the provider does not provide a requirement for appropriate handling of classified data.
justification.C: Ensuring the data classification requirements exceed those of the outsourcer is an acceptable option but not as comprehensive or as binding as a legal contract.
justification.D: The most effective mechanism to ensure that the enterprise's security standards are met by a third party would be a legal agreement stating the handling requirements for classified data and including the right to inspect and audit.

question: What is the GREATEST risk when there are an excessive number of firewall rules?

options.A: One rule may override another rule in the chain and create a loophole.
options.B: Performance degradation of the whole network may occur.
options.C: The firewall may not support the increasing number of rules due to limitations.
options.D: The firewall may show abnormal behavior and may crash or automatically shut down.

justification.A: If there are many firewall rules, there is a chance that a particular rule may allow an external connection although other associated rules are overridden. Due to the increasing number of rules, it becomes complex to test them and, over time, a loophole may occur.
justification.B: Excessive firewall rules may impact network performance, but this is a secondary concern.
justification.C: It is unlikely that the capacity to support rules will exceed capacity and it is not a significant risk.
justification.D: There is a slight risk that the firewall will behave erratically, but that is not the greatest risk.

question: Which of the following is MOST likely to be discretionary?

justification.A: Policies define management's security goals and expectations for an enterprise. These are defined in more specific terms within standards and procedures and cannot be discretionary.
justification.B: Procedures describe how work is to be done and, as they are a defined set of actions, they cannot be discretionary.
justification.C: Guidelines provide recommendations that business management must consider in developing practices within their areas of control; therefore, they are most likely to be discretionary.
justification.D: Standards establish the allowable operational boundaries for people, processes and technology and cannot be discretionary.

question: Which of the following are seldom changed in response to technological changes?

justification.A: Security standards must be revised and updated based on the impact of technology changes.
justification.B: Procedures must be revised and updated based on the impact of technology or standards changes.
justification.C: Policies are high-level statements of management intent and direction, which is not likely to be affected by technological changes.
justification.D: Guidelines must be revised and updated based on the impact of technology changes.

question: What is the BEST way to ensure data protection upon termination of employment?

options.A: Retrieve identification badge and card keys.
options.D: Ensure all logical access is removed.

justification.A: Retrieving identification badge and card keys would only reduce the capability to enter the building.
justification.B: Retrieving the personal computer equipment is a necessary task but does not prevent access to resources.
justification.C: Erasing the employee's folders is not reasonable because the folders may contain information important to the enterprise.
justification.D: Ensuring that all logical access is removed will guarantee that the former employee will not be able to access company data and that the employee's credentials will not be misused.

question: What is the MOST important reason for formally documenting security procedures?

options.A: Ensure processes are repeatable and sustainable.
options.D: Ensure objective criteria for the application of metrics.

justification.A: Without formal documentation, it would be difficult to ensure that security processes are performed correctly and consistently.
justification.B: Alignment with business objectives is not a function of formally documenting security procedures.
justification.C: Processes should not be formally documented merely to satisfy an audit requirement.
justification.D: Although potentially useful in the development of metrics, creating formal documentation to assist in the creation of metrics is a secondary objective.

question: Which of the following is the BEST approach for an enterprise desiring to protect its intellectual property?

options.A: Conduct awareness sessions on intellectual property policy.
options.B: Require all employees to sign a nondisclosure agreement.
options.C: Promptly remove all access when an employee leaves the enterprise.
options.D: Restrict access to a need-to-know basis.

justification.A: Security awareness regarding intellectual property policy will not prevent violations of this policy.
justification.B: Requiring all employees to sign a nondisclosure agreement is a good control but not as effective as restricting access to a need-to-know basis.
justification.C: Removing all access at termination does not protect intellectual property prior to an employee leaving.
justification.D: Restricting access to a need-to-know basis is the most effective approach to protecting intellectual property.

question: When creating an effective data-protection strategy, the information security manager must understand the flow of data and its protection at various stages. This is BEST achieved with:

options.B: a tailored methodology based on exposure.
options.C: an insurance policy for accidental data losses.
options.D: a tokenization system set up in a secure network environment.

justification.A: Vulnerability assessments, third-party or otherwise, do not provide information about data flow, risk or threats that is needed to create a data protection strategy.
justification.B: Enterprises classify data according to business value and risk exposure. The enterprise can then develop a sensible plan to invest budget and effort to create the data protection strategy based on the information gathered about the data assets.
justification.C: An insurance policy is a risk treatment option for the transfer/sharing of risk and does not provide the information necessary for creating a data protection strategy.
justification.D: Tokenization is a technique used to protect data, and not a method to ascertain data flow or other attributes relevant and necessary to create the data protection strategy.

question: An account with full administrative privileges over a production file is found to be accessible by a member of the software development team. This account was set up to allow the developer to download nonsensitive production data for software testing purposes. Assuming all options are possible, which of the following should the information security manager recommend?

options.B: Log all usage of this account.
options.C: Suspend the account and activate only when needed.
options.D: Require that a change request be submitted for each download.

justification.A: Administrative accounts have permission to change data. This is not required for the developers to perform their tasks. Unauthorized change will damage the integrity of the data. Restricting the account to read-only access will ensure that file integrity can be maintained while permitting access.
justification.B: Logging all usage of the account is a detective control and will not reduce the exposure created by this excessive level of access.
justification.C: Suspending the account and activating only when needed will not reduce the exposure created by this excessive level of access.
justification.D: Requiring that a change request be submitted for each download would be excessively burdensome and will not reduce the exposure created by this excessive level of access.

question: Which of the following is the BEST indicator that security controls are performing effectively?

options.A: The monthly service level statistics indicate minimal impact from security issues.
options.B: The cost of implementing security controls is less than the value of the assets.
options.C: The percentage of systems that are compliant with security standards is satisfactory.
options.D: Audit reports do not reflect any significant findings on security.

justification.A: The best indicator of effective security control is the evidence of acceptable disruption to business operations.
justification.B: The cost of implementing controls is unrelated to their effectiveness.
justification.C: The percentage of systems that are compliant with security standards is not an indicator of their effectiveness.
justification.D: Audit reports that do not reflect any significant findings on security can support this evidence, but this is generally not sufficiently frequent to be a useful management tool and is only supplemental to monthly service level statistics.

question: Segregation of duties (SoD) has been designed and introduced into an accounts payable system. Which of the following should be in place to BEST maintain the effectiveness of SoD?

options.A: A strong password rule is assigned to disbursement staff.
options.B: Security awareness is publicized by the compliance department.
options.C: An operational role matrix is aligned with the organizational chart.
options.D: Access privilege is reviewed when an operator's role changes.

justification.A: Password strength is important for each staff member, but complexity of passwords does not ensure effectiveness of segregation of duties (SoD).
justification.B: Effective SoD is not based on self-governance, so security awareness is an inadequate control for the same.
justification.C: It is not uncommon for staff to have ancillary roles beyond what is shown on the organizational chart, so aligning a role matrix with the organizational chart is not sufficiently granular to maintain the effectiveness of SoD.
justification.D: In order to maintain the effectiveness of SoD established in an application system, user access privilege must be reviewed whenever an operator's role changes. If this effort is neglected, there is a risk that a single staff member could acquire excessive operational capabilities. For instance, if a cash disbursement staff member accidentally acquires a trade input role, this person is technically able to accomplish an illegal payment operation.

question: Several business units reported problems with their systems after multiple security patches were deployed. What is the FIRST step to handle this problem?

options.A: Assess the problems and institute rollback procedures, if needed.
options.B: Disconnect the systems from the network until the problems are corrected.
options.C: Uninstall the patches from these systems.
options.D: Contact the vendor regarding the problems that occurred.

justification.A: Assessing the problems and instituting rollback procedures as needed would be the best course of action.
justification.B: Disconnecting the systems from the network would not identify where the problem was and may make the problem worse.
justification.C: Uninstalling the patches would not identify where the problem was and would recreate the risk the patches were meant to address.
justification.D: Contacting the vendor regarding the problems that occurred is part of the assessment.

question: Information security frameworks can be MOST useful for the information security manager because they:

options.B: are designed to achieve specific outcomes.

justification.A: Frameworks are general structures and will not provide detailed processes and methods.
justification.B: Frameworks do not specify particular outcomes but may provide the structure to assess outcomes against requirements.
justification.C: Frameworks are like a skeleton; they provide the outlines and basic structure but not the specifics of process and outcomes.
justification.D: Frameworks do not specify or provide policies and procedures. The creation of policy/procedure documents is left to the implementer who may follow a documentation framework.

question: In which of the following situations is continuous monitoring the BEST option?

options.A: Where incidents may have a high impact and frequency
options.B: Where legislation requires strong information security controls
options.C: Where incidents may have a high impact but low frequency
options.D: Where e-commerce is a primary business driver

justification.A: Continuous monitoring control initiatives are expensive, so they should be used in areas where the risk is at its greatest level. These areas are the ones with high impact and high frequency of occurrence.
justification.B: Regulations and legislation that require tight IT security measures focus on requiring enterprises to establish an IT security governance structure that manages IT security with a risk-based approach, so each enterprise decides which kinds of controls are implemented. Continuous monitoring is not necessarily a requirement.
justification.C: Measures such as contingency planning or insurance are commonly used when incidents rarely happen but have a high impact each time they happen. Continuous monitoring is unlikely to be necessary.
justification.D: Continuous control monitoring initiatives are not needed in all e-commerce environments. There are some e-commerce environments where the impact of incidents is not high enough to support the implementation of this kind of initiative.

question: An information security manager mapping a job description to types of data access is MOST likely to adhere to which of the following information security principles?

justification.A: Ethics is expected to be part of all job roles but has no relation to types of data access. Ethics has no relevance to mapping a job description to types of data access.
justification.B: Information security controls, including access, should be proportionate to the criticality and/or sensitivity of the asset (i.e., the potential impact of compromise). This is termed the principle of proportionality.
justification.C: Principles of integration are not relevant to mapping a job description to types of data access.
justification.D: The principle of accountability would be the second most-adhered-to principle because people with access to data may not always be accountable.

question: What is the BIGGEST concern for an information security manager reviewing firewall rules?

justification.A: If the firewall allows source routing, any outsider can carry out spoofing attacks by stealing the internal (private) Internet Protocol addresses of the enterprise.
justification.B: Broadcast propagation does not create a significant security exposure.
justification.C: Unregistered ports are a poor practice but do not necessarily create a significant security exposure.
justification.D: Nonstandard protocols can be filtered and do not necessarily create a significant security exposure.

question: What is the MOST cost-effective means of improving security awareness of staff personnel?

justification.A: Incentives perform poorly without user education and training.
justification.B: User education and training is the most cost-effective means of influencing staff to improve security because personnel are the weakest link in security.
justification.C: Unless users are aware of the security requirements, a zero-tolerance security policy would not be as good as education and training.
justification.D: Users would not have the knowledge to accurately interpret and report violations without user education and training.

question: Which of the following is the MOST effective at preventing an unauthorized individual from following an authorized person through a secured entrance (tailgating or piggybacking)?

justification.A: Card key door locks are a physical control that by itself would not be effective against tailgating.
justification.B: Photo identification is a detective control that by itself would not prevent tailgating.
justification.C: Biometric scanners would not prevent tailgating.
justification.D: Awareness training is more likely to result in any attempted tailgating being challenged by the authorized employee.

question: How will data owners determine what access and authorizations users will have?

justification.A: Data custodians implement the decisions made by data owners.
justification.B: Access and authorizations are not to be assigned by cloning existing user accounts. By cloning, users may obtain more access rights and privileges than are required to do their job.
justification.C: Access and authorizations should be based on a need-to-know basis. Hierarchical preferences may be based on individual preferences and not on business needs.
justification.D: Access and authorizations should be based on business needs.

question: Which of the following is the MOST likely outcome of a well-designed information security awareness course?

options.A: Increased reporting of security incidents to the incident response function
options.B: Decreased reporting of security incidents to the incident response function
options.C: Decrease in the number of password resets
options.D: Increase in the number of identified system vulnerabilities

justification.A: A well-organized information security awareness course informs all employees of existing security policies, the importance of following safe practices for data security, and the need to report any possible security incidents to the appropriate individuals in the enterprise.
justification.B: Decreased reporting of security incidents would not be a likely outcome.
justification.C: A decrease in the number of password resets would not be a likely outcome.
justification.D: An increase in the number of identified system vulnerabilities would not be a likely outcome.

question: Which item would be the BEST to include in the information security awareness training program for new general staff employees?

options.B: Discussion of how to construct strong passwords
options.C: Review of roles that have privileged access

justification.A: A review of various security models would not be applicable to general staff employees.
justification.B: All new employees will need to understand techniques for the construction of strong passwords.
justification.C: A review of roles that have privileged access would not be applicable to general staff employees.
justification.D: A discussion of vulnerability assessment results would not be applicable to general staff employees.

question: What is a critical component of a continuous improvement program for information security?

options.B: Developing a service level agreement for security
options.C: Tying corporate security standards to a recognized international standard

justification.A: If an enterprise is unable to take measurements over time that provide data regarding key aspects of its security program, then continuous improvement is not likely.
justification.B: Although desirable, developing a service level agreement for security is not a critical component for a continuous improvement program.
justification.C: Tying corporate security standards to a recognized international standard is not a critical component for a continuous improvement program.
justification.D: Ensuring regulatory compliance is a separate issue and is not a critical component for a continuous improvement program.

question: An enterprise has implemented an enterprise resource planning system used by 500 employees from various departments. Which of the following access control approaches is MOST appropriate?

justification.A: Rule-based access control needs to define the individual access rules, which is troublesome and error prone in large enterprises.
justification.B: In mandatory access control, the individual's access to information resources is based on a clearance level that needs to be defined, which is troublesome in large enterprises.
justification.C: In discretionary access control, users have access to resources based on delegation of rights by someone with the proper authority, which requires a significant amount of administration and overhead.
justification.D: Role-based access control is effective and efficient in large user communities because it controls system access by the roles defined for groups of users. Users are assigned to the various roles and the system controls the access based on those roles.

question: An enterprise plans to contract with an outside service provider to host its corporate website. The MOST important concern for the information security manager is to ensure that:

options.A: an audit of the service provider uncovers no significant weakness.
options.B: the contract includes a nondisclosure agreement to protect the enterprise’s intellectual property.
options.C: the contract should mandate that the service provider will comply with security policies.
options.D: the third-party service provider conducts regular penetration testing.

justification.A: The audit is normally a one-time effort and cannot provide ongoing assurance of the security.
justification.B: A nondisclosure agreement should be part of the contract and would be a part of the policy compliance requirements.
justification.C: It is critical to include the security requirements in the contract based on the company’s security policy to ensure that the necessary security controls are implemented by the service provider.
justification.D: Penetration testing alone would not provide total security to the website; there are many controls that cannot be tested through penetration testing.

question: Which of the following is the MAIN objective in contracting with an external company to perform penetration testing?

options.B: To have an independent certification of network security
options.C: To receive an independent view of security exposures
options.D: To identify a complete list of vulnerabilities

justification.A: Mitigating technical risk is not a direct result of a penetration test.
justification.B: A penetration test would not provide certification of network security.
justification.C: Even though the enterprise may have the capability to perform penetration testing with internal resources, third-party penetration testing should be performed to gain an independent view of the security exposure.
justification.D: A penetration test would not provide a complete list of vulnerabilities.

question: The MOST important characteristic of good security policies is that they:

options.B: state only one general security mandate.
options.D: govern the creation of procedures and guidelines.

justification.A: Stating expectations of IT management omits addressing overall organizational goals and objectives.
justification.B: Stating only one general security mandate is the next best option because policies should be clear; otherwise, policies may be confusing and difficult to understand and enforce.
justification.C: The most important characteristic of good security policies is that they are aligned with organizational goals. Failure to align policies and goals makes them ineffective and potentially misleading in governing the creation of standards and procedures.
justification.D: Policies are created with the objective to govern the creation of procedures and guidelines by design.

question: Which of the following would raise security awareness among an enterprise's employees?

options.A: Distributing industry statistics about security incidents
options.C: Encouraging employees to behave in a more conscious manner

justification.A: Distributing industry statistics about security incidents would have little bearing on the employee's behavior.
justification.B: Monitoring the magnitude of incidents does not involve the employees.
justification.C: Encouraging employees to behave in a more conscious manner could be an aspect of continual reinforcement of the security policy.
justification.D: Employees must be continually made aware of the policy and expectations for their behavior.

question: Which of the following is the MOST appropriate method of ensuring password strength in a large enterprise?

options.A: Attempt to reset several passwords to weaker values
options.B: Install code to capture passwords for periodic audit
options.C: Sample a subset of users and request their passwords for review
options.D: Automatic password strength determination on each platform

justification.A: Attempting to reset several passwords to weaker values will not ensure adequate password strength.
justification.B: Installing code to capture passwords for periodic audit creates an unnecessary risk.
justification.C: Sampling a subset of users and requesting their passwords for review would compromise the integrity of the passwords.
justification.D: Automatic testing of password strength and enforcing proper construction is the most effective way of ensuring strong password construction.

question: Which of the following is the BEST approach for improving information security management processes?

justification.A: Audits will identify deficiencies in established controls; however, they are not effective in evaluating the overall performance for improvement on an ongoing basis.
justification.B: Penetration testing will only uncover technical vulnerabilities and cannot provide a holistic picture of information security management.
justification.C: Defining and monitoring security metrics is a good approach to analyze the performance of the security management process since it determines the baseline and evaluates the performance against the baseline to identify opportunities for improvement. This is a systematic and structured approach to process improvement.
justification.D: Feedback is subjective and not necessarily reflective of true performance.

question: What should metrics be based on when measuring and monitoring information security programs?

justification.A: Metrics are used to measure not only the results of the security controls (residual risk) but also the attributes of the control implementation.
justification.B: Levels of security are only relevant in relation to the security objectives.
justification.C: Metrics should be developed based on security objectives, so they can measure the effectiveness and efficiency of information security controls in relation to the defined objectives.
justification.D: Statistics of security incidents provide a general basis for determining if overall outcomes are meeting expectations, but they do not provide a basis for the achievement of individual objectives.

question: Which of the following is the BEST justification to convince management to invest in an information security program?

justification.A: Cost reduction by itself is rarely the motivator for implementing an information security program.
justification.B: Compliance is secondary to business value and cannot be the best justification, as the company may already be in compliance as managed by the legal team.
justification.C: Protection of business assets is not the best justification, as management can counter it by stating that it can ensure protection of assets.
justification.D: Investing in an information security program would increase business value as a result of fewer business disruptions, fewer losses, increased productivity and stronger brand reputation.

question: An enterprise is entering into an agreement with a new business partner to conduct customer mailings. What is the MOST important action that the information security manager needs to perform?

options.A: A due diligence security review of the business partner's security controls
options.B: Ensuring that the business partner has an effective business continuity program
options.C: Ensuring that the third party is contractually obligated to all relevant security requirements
options.D: Talking to other clients of the business partner to check references for performance

justification.A: A due diligence security review is contributory to the contractual agreement but not key.
justification.B: Ensuring that the business partner has an effective business continuity program is contributory to the contractual agreement but not key.
justification.C: The key requirement is that the information security manager ensure that the third party is contractually bound to follow the appropriate security requirements for the process being outsourced. This protects both enterprises.
justification.D: Talking to other clients of the business partner is contributory to the contractual agreement but not key.

question: An enterprise that outsourced its payroll processing needs to perform independent assessments of the security controls of the third party, according to policy requirements. Which of the following is the MOST useful requirement to include in the contract?

options.D: Dedicated security manager for monitoring compliance

justification.A: Right to audit would be the most useful requirement because it would provide the company with the ability to perform a security audit/assessment in response to a business need to examine whether the controls are working effectively at the third party.
justification.B: A nondisclosure agreement is an important requirement and can be examined during the audit.
justification.C: Proper firewall implementation would not be a specific requirement in the contract but part of general control requirements.
justification.D: A dedicated security manager would be a costly solution and not feasible for most situations.

question: Which of the following is the MOST critical activity to ensure the ongoing security of outsourced IT services?

options.A: Provide security awareness training to the third-party provider's employees.
options.B: Conduct regular security reviews of the third-party provider.
options.C: Include security requirements in the service contract.
options.D: Request that the third-party provider comply with the enterprise's information security policy.

justification.A: Depending on the type of services outsourced, security awareness training may not be relevant or necessary.
justification.B: Regular security audits and reviews of the practices of the provider to prevent potential information security damage will help verify the security of outsourced services.
justification.C: Security requirements should be included in the contract, but what is most important is verifying that the requirements are met by the provider.
justification.D: It is not necessary to require the provider to fully comply with the policy if only some of the policy is related and applicable.

question: A virtual desktop infrastructure enables remote access. The benefit of this approach from a security perspective is to:

options.A: optimize the IT resource budget by reducing physical maintenance to remote personal computers (PCs).
options.B: establish segregation of personal and organizational data while using a remote PC.
options.C: enable the execution of data wipe operations into a remote PC environment.
options.D: terminate the update of the approved antivirus software list for remote PCs.

justification.A: Physical maintenance is reduced in a virtual desktop infrastructure (VDI) environment, but cost reduction is not the benefit of VDI from a security perspective.
justification.B: The major benefit of introducing a VDI is to establish remote desktop hosting while keeping personal areas in a client personal computer (PC) separate. This serves as a control against unauthorized copies of business data on a user PC.
justification.C: Remote data wiping is not possible in a VDI.
justification.D: Termination of antivirus updates may represent a cost savings to the enterprise, but the presence or absence of antivirus software on a remote PC is irrelevant in a VDI context.

question: Which of the following BEST ensures that security risk will be reevaluated when modifications in application developments are made?

justification.A: Problem management is the general process intended to manage all problems, not those specifically related to security.
justification.B: Background screening is the process of evaluating employee references when they are hired.
justification.C: A change control process is the methodology that ensures that anything that could be impacted by a development change will be reevaluated.
justification.D: Business impact analysis is the methodology used to evaluate impacts and the cost of losing a particular function.

question: In which of the following system development life cycle phases are access control and encryption algorithms chosen?

justification.A: The procedural design converts structural components into a procedural description of the software.
justification.B: The architectural design is the phase that identifies the overall system design but not the specifics
justification.C: The system design specifications phase is the phase that identifies security specifications.
justification.D: Software development is too late a stage because during this phase the system is already being coded.

question: Which of the following is generally considered a fundamental component of an information security program?

justification.A: Role-based access control systems may not be necessary; they are discretionary.
justification.B: Automated access provisioning may not be necessary; they are discretionary.
justification.C: Without security awareness training, many components of the security program may not be effectively implemented.
justification.D: Intrusion prevention systems may not be necessary; they are discretionary.

question: How would an enterprise know if its new information security program is accomplishing its goals?

options.A: Key metrics indicate a reduction in incident impacts.
options.B: Senior management has approved the program and is supportive of it.
options.C: Employees are receptive to changes that were implemented.
options.D: There is an immediate reduction in reported incidents.

justification.A: An effective security program will show a trend in impact reduction.
justification.B: Senior management support may result from a performing program but is not as significant as key metrics indicating a reduction in incident impacts.
justification.C: Receptive employees may result from a performing program but are not as significant as key metrics indicating a reduction in incident impacts.
justification.D: An immediate reduction in reported incidents is likely to be from other causes and not a good indicator of the program achieving its goals.

question: A benefit of using a full disclosure (white box) approach as compared to a blind (black box) approach to penetration testing is that:

options.A: it simulates the real-life situation of an external security attack.
options.B: human intervention is not required for this type of test.
options.C: less time is spent on reconnaissance and information gathering.
options.D: critical infrastructure information is not revealed to the tester.

justification.A: Blind (black box) penetration testing is closer to real life than full disclosure (white box) testing.
justification.B: There is no evidence to support that human intervention is not required for this type of test.
justification.C: Data and information required for penetration are shared with the testers, thus eliminating time that would otherwise have been spent on reconnaissance and gathering of information.
justification.D: A full disclosure (white box) methodology requires the knowledge of the subject being tested.

question: An enterprise is MOST likely to include an indemnity clause in a service level agreement because an indemnity clause:

options.A: reduces the likelihood of an incident.

justification.A: The indemnity clause would not reduce the likelihood of an incident.
justification.B: An indemnity clause is a compensating control that serves to reduce impact if the provider causes financial loss.
justification.C: An indemnity clause is generally not a regulatory requirement.
justification.D: An indemnity clause may provide an incentive to perform but will not ensure it.

question: Which of the following is the BEST approach to mitigate online brute force attacks on user accounts?

options.C: Strong passwords that are changed periodically

justification.A: Passwords stored in encrypted form will not defeat an online brute force attack if the password itself is easily guessed.
justification.B: User awareness would help to inform users to use strong passwords but would not mitigate an online brute force attack.
justification.C: In cases where implementation of account lockout policies is not possible, strong passwords that are changed periodically would be an appropriate choice.
justification.D: Implementation of account lockout policies significantly inhibits brute force attacks.

question: Which of the following measures is the MOST effective deterrent against disgruntled staff abusing their privileges?

justification.A: A layered defense strategy would only prevent those activities that are outside the user's privileges.
justification.B: System audit log monitoring is after the fact and may not be effective.
justification.C: A signed acceptable use policy is often an effective deterrent against malicious activities because of the stated potential for termination of employment and/or legal actions being taken against the individual.
justification.D: High-availability systems do not deter staff abusing privileges.

question: What is an advantage of sending messages using steganographic techniques as opposed to using encryption?

options.A: The existence of messages is unknown
options.D: Reliability of the data is higher in transit

justification.A: The existence of messages is hidden in another file, such as a JPEG image, when using steganography.
justification.B: Some implementations count on security through obscurity and others require keys, which may or may not be smaller.
justification.C: Sniffing of steganographic traffic is possible.
justification.D: The reliability of the data is not relevant.

question: There is reason to believe that a recently modified web application has allowed unauthorized access. Which is the BEST way to identify an application back door?

justification.A: Application back doors are almost impossible to identify using a black box penetration test.
justification.B: Security audits will not detect an application back door.
justification.C: Source code review is typically the only way to find and remove an application back door.
justification.D: A vulnerability scan will only find known vulnerability patterns and therefore will not find a programmer's application back door.

question: Which of the following vulnerabilities is commonly introduced when using Simple Network Management Protocol v2 (SNMP v2) to monitor networks?

justification.A: There have been some isolated cases of remote buffer overflows against Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) daemons, but generally this is not a problem.
justification.B: Cross-site scripting is a web application vulnerability that is not related to SNMP.
justification.C: One of the main problems with using SNMP v1 and v2 is the cleartext community string that it uses to authenticate. It is easy to sniff and reuse. Most times, the SNMP community string is shared throughout the enterprise's servers and routers, making this authentication problem a serious threat to security.
justification.D: A man-in-the-middle attack against a User Datagram Protocol makes no sense since there is no active session; every request has the community string and is answered independently.

question: Which of the following is the FIRST phase in which security should be addressed in the development cycle of a project?

justification.A: Security requirements must be defined before doing design specification, although changes in design may alter these requirements later on.
justification.B: Security requirements defined during system implementation are typically costly add-ons that are frequently ineffective.
justification.C: Application security testing occurs after security has been implemented.
justification.D: Information security should be considered at the earliest possible stage because it may affect feasibility of the project.

question: A company has installed biometric fingerprint scanners at all entrances in response to a management requirement for better access control. Due to the large number of employees coupled with a slow system response, it takes a substantial amount of time for all workers to gain access to the building and workers are increasingly piggybacking. What is the BEST course of action for the information security manager to address this issue?

options.A: Replace the system for better response time.
options.C: Revert to manual entry control procedures.

justification.A: Upgrading the system is likely to be a costly option and is a management issue.
justification.B: It is a business decision how management wants to deal with the problem, not directly a security issue. Conflicts of this nature are best addressed by management.
justification.C: Given that management has set the requirement, it is unlikely that going back to a manual entry control system will be acceptable.
justification.D: Increasing compliance efforts does not address the underlying issue. Regardless, such a choice should be made by management.

question: Which of the following metrics is the MOST useful for the effectiveness of a controls monitoring program?

options.A: The percentage of key controls being monitored
options.B: The time between detection and initiating remediation
options.C: The monitoring cost versus incidents detected
options.D: The time between an incident and detection

justification.A: While the percentage of key controls being monitored is an important metric, it is not an indication of effectiveness.
justification.B: The time between detection and remediation is an indication of the effectiveness of the incident response activity.
justification.C: The monitoring cost per incident is an indicator of efficiency rather than effectiveness.
justification.D: The time it takes to detect an incident after it has occurred is a good indication of the effectiveness of the control monitoring effort.

question: Achieving compliance with a particular process in an information security standard selected by management would BEST be demonstrated by:

justification.A: A key goal indicator defines a clear objective sought by an enterprise. A key goal indicator is defined as a measure that tells management, after the fact, whether an IT process has achieved its business requirements, usually expressed in terms of information criteria.
justification.B: Critical success factors are steps that must be achieved to accomplish high-level goals. A critical success factor is defined as the most important issue or action for management to achieve control over its IT processes.
justification.C: A key performance indicator (KPI) indicates how well a process is progressing according to expectations. Another definition for a key performance indicator is a measure that determines how well the process is performing in enabling the goal to be reached.
justification.D: A business impact analysis defines risk impact; its main purpose is not to achieve compliance. It is defined as an exercise that determines the impact of losing the support of any resource to an enterprise. It establishes the escalation of that loss over time, identifies the minimum resources needed to recover, and prioritizes the recovery of processes and the supporting system.

question: What would be the MOST significant security risk when using wireless local area network technology?

justification.A: Man-in-the-middle attacks can occur in any media and are not dependent on the use of a wireless local area network (WLAN) technology.
justification.B: Spoofing of data packets is not dependent on the use of a WLAN technology.
justification.C: A rogue access point masquerades as a legitimate access point. The risk is that legitimate users may connect through this access point and have their traffic monitored.
justification.D: Session hijacking is not dependent on the use of a WLAN technology.

question: Which of the following will BEST prevent external security attacks?

options.D: Securing and analyzing system access logs

justification.A: Static Internet Protocol addressing is helpful to an attacker.
justification.B: Network address translation is helpful by having internal addresses that are non-routable.
justification.C: Background checks of temporary employees are more likely to prevent an attack launched from within the enterprise.
justification.D: Writing all computer logs to removable media does not prevent an attack.

question: How should an information security manager determine the selection of controls required to meet business objectives?

options.A: Prioritize the use of role-based access controls.

justification.A: Prioritizing the use of role-based access controls could be an example of possible key controls but is only one of the typical key controls.
justification.B: Key controls are the essential controls to reduce risk and are most effective for the protection of information assets.
justification.C: Controls cannot be restricted to critical applications because, in many cases, noncritical applications can provide access to critical ones.
justification.D: Focusing on automated controls would eliminate many essential non-automated key controls such as policies, standards, procedures and necessary physical controls.

question: What is the purpose of a corrective control?

justification.A: Preventive controls, such as firewalls, reduce the occurrence of adverse events.
justification.B: Compromise can be detected by detective controls, such as intrusion detection systems.
justification.C: Corrective controls serve to reduce or mitigate impacts, such as providing recovery capabilities.
justification.D: Compliance can be ensured by preventive controls, such as access controls.

question: The enactment of policies and procedures for preventing hacker intrusions is an example of an activity that belongs to:

justification.A: Risk management is about identifying risk and adequate countermeasures and would be concerned if such policies and procedures were necessary, based on a risk analysis. However, the enactment does not fall into the area of risk management.
justification.B: Compliance would be concerned with the adequacy of the policies and procedures to achieve the control objectives and whether employees acted according to the policies and procedures.
justification.C: IT management would be concerned about setting the policies into operation (e.g., by providing training and resources).
justification.D: Governance is concerned with implementing adequate mechanisms for ensuring that organizational goals and objectives can be achieved. Policies and procedures are common governance mechanisms.

question: What is the BEST method for detecting and monitoring a hacker's activities without exposing information assets to unnecessary risk?

justification.A: Firewalls attempt to keep the hacker out.
justification.B: Bastion hosts attempt to keep the hacker out.
justification.C: Decoy files, often referred to as honeypots, are the best choice for diverting a hacker away from critical files and alerting security of the hacker's presence.
justification.D: Screened subnets or demilitarized zones provide a middle ground between the trusted internal network and the external untrusted Internet but do not help detect hacker activities.

question: Which of the following would be the BEST way to improve employee attitude toward, and commitment to, information security?

options.B: Customize methods training to the audience.

justification.A: Implementing restrictive controls may improve compliance but is not likely to improve attitude.
justification.B: Cultural differences will dictate the best behavior modification techniques to customize training. For example, some cultures value relationships over monetary rewards.
justification.C: Applying administrative penalties may increase compliance but is likely to have a negative effect on attitudes.
justification.D: Initiating stronger supervision may improve attitudes in certain circumstances, enterprises and geographic locations, but not in others.

question: When considering outsourcing services, at what point should information security become involved in the vendor management process?

options.B: Upon request for assistance from the business unit

justification.A: Waiting until later in the process can lead to vendors having to re-bid and can disrupt negotiations.
justification.B: There may be situations where information security involvement is not required, but those situations would be established by conducting an initial risk assessment.
justification.C: Information security should be involved in the vendor or third-party management process from the beginning of the selection process, when the business is defining what it needs. This will ensure that all bids for the service take into consideration, and reflect in bid prices, the security requirements.
justification.D: Waiting until after the contract is signed when an incident occurs can expose the enterprise to significant security risk, with little recourse to correct, because the contract has already been executed.

question: An information security manager has decided to implement a security system to monitor access to the Internet and prevent access to numerous sites. Immediately upon installation, employees flood the IT help desk with complaints of being unable to perform business functions on Internet sites. This is an example of:

options.A: conflicting security controls with organizational needs.
options.C: implementing appropriate controls to reduce risk.

justification.A: The needs of the enterprise were not considered, so there is a conflict.
justification.B: This example is not strong protection as it pertains to enabling restrictions and not safeguards.
justification.C: A control that significantly restricts the ability of users to do their job is not appropriate.
justification.D: Proving protection abilities at an unacceptable cost or performance is a poor strategy. This control does not prove the ability to protect but proves the ability to interfere with business.

question: Which of the following is the MOST critical success factor of an information security program?

options.A: Developing information security policies and procedures
options.C: Conducting security training and awareness for all users
options.D: Establishing an information security management system

justification.A: Developing policies and procedures is important, but without senior management commitment, implementation will be difficult.
justification.B: Without senior management commitment, it would be difficult to implement a successful information security program.
justification.C: Conducting training and awareness exercises is not the most critical success factor.
justification.D: Establishing an information security management system is essential, but without management support and commitment, it is unlikely to be successful.

question: How does the development of an information security program begin?

options.C: The controls statement of applicability is completed.

justification.A: Assessing and analyzing risk is required to develop a strategy and will provide some of the information needed to develop the strategy that will achieve the desired outcomes, but it will not define the scope and charter of the security program.
justification.B: A security architecture is a part of implementation after developing the strategy.
justification.C: The applicability statement is a part of strategy implementation using International Organization for Standardization (ISO) 27001 or 27002 after determining the scope and responsibilities of the program.
justification.D: After management has determined the desired outcomes of the information security program, development of a strategy can begin, together with initiating the process of developing information security governance structures, achieving organizational adoption and developing an implementation strategy that will define the scope and responsibilities of the security program.

question: Which of the following constitutes the MAIN project activities undertaken in developing an information security program?

justification.A: The majority of program development activities will involve designing, testing and deploying controls that achieve the risk management objectives.
justification.B: The security enterprise should be fairly well-developed prior to attempting to implement a security program.
justification.C: Conceptual and logical architecture designs should have been completed as a part of strategy and road map development.
justification.D: Risk management objectives are part of strategy development.

question: Who is accountable for ensuring that information is categorized and that specific protective measures are taken?

justification.A: The security officer assumes responsibility, as this role supports and implements information security to achieve senior management objectives.
justification.B: While routine administration and operations of all aspects of security may be delegated, top management must retain overall accountability.
justification.C: The end user is not responsible for ensuring that information is categorized and that specific protective measures are taken.
justification.D: The custodian supports and implements information security measures as directed and is not responsible for ensuring that information is categorized and that specific protective measures are taken.

question: Information security should:

options.D: be defined by the board of directors.

justification.A: It is not practical or feasible to eliminate all risk.
justification.B: Information security should ensure that business objectives are met given available technical capabilities, resource constraints and compliance requirements.
justification.C: The extent of compliance with regulatory requirements is a business decision and must be defined by management.
justification.D: Defining information security is an executive and operational function, not a board function.

question: Which is the FIRST thing that should be determined by the information security manager when developing an information security program?

justification.A: Control objectives cannot be determined until desired outcomes have been determined and subsequent specific objectives defined.
justification.B: Without determining the desired outcomes of the security program, the strategic aims that would lead to the desired outcomes cannot be determined.
justification.C: Without determining the desired outcomes of the security program, it will be difficult or impossible to determine a viable strategy, control objectives and logical architecture.
justification.D: Architecture is the physical manifestation of policy which is developed after and in support of strategy development.

question: Which of the following is the BEST way to mitigate the risk of the database administrator reading sensitive data from the database?

options.A: Log all access to sensitive data.

justification.A: Access logging can be easily turned off by the database administrator.
justification.B: Data encrypted at the application level that is stored in a database cannot be viewed in cleartext by the database administrator.
justification.C: A database monitoring solution can be bypassed by the database administrator.
justification.D: A security policy will only be effective if the database administrator chooses to adhere to the policy.

question: In a large enterprise, what makes an information security awareness program MOST effective?

options.A: The program is developed by a professional training company.
options.B: The program is embedded into the orientation process.
options.C: The program is customized to the audience using the appropriate delivery channel.
options.D: The program is required by the information security policy.

justification.A: It does not have to be developed by a professional training company to make it effective.
justification.B: The awareness program should be embedded into the orientation process for new employees, but that does not necessarily indicate efficacy.
justification.C: An awareness program should be customized for different types of audiences (e.g., for new employees, system administration, sales and delivery channels such as posters or e-learning).
justification.D: Being required by policy does not make the program more effective.

question: What is the PRIMARY basis for the prioritization of security spending and budgeting?

options.D: The allocated revenue of the enterprise

justification.A: The first required action is to conduct a risk assessment of the enterprise's key processes to identify control gaps and determine where investments should be made to mitigate risk and to determine order of prioritization. This must be conducted with consideration of enterprise goals and strategy.
justification.B: Prioritization should not be based on the trends at other enterprises because each enterprise has unique requirements and business objectives.
justification.C: Prioritization by cost alone is not aligned with a risk-based approach.
justification.D: Although the revenue may increase, it is not wise to link the IT budget to a fixed percentage of revenue because this could lead to spending more or less than is necessary to effectively address risk.

question: Which of the following will the data backup policy contain?

options.D: A list of systems to be backed up

justification.A: A policy is a high-level statement of management intent and will essentially contain the criteria to be followed for backing up any data such as critical data, confidential data and project data, and the frequency of backup.
justification.B: A list of personnel responsible for backup is a procedural detail and will not be included in the data backup policy.
justification.C: A data backup schedule is a procedural detail and will not be included in the data backup policy.
justification.D: A list of systems to be backed up is a procedural detail and will not be included in the data backup policy.

question: Which of the following roles is MOST appropriately responsible for ensuring that security awareness and training material is effectively deployed to reach the intended audience?

justification.A: The human resources department may assist in disseminating security awareness material but the primary responsibility rests with the information security department.
justification.B: The business manager may also assist in information dissemination but is not primarily responsible.
justification.C: Subject matter experts are not normally involved with security awareness activities.
justification.D: The information security department oversees the information security program. This includes ensuring that training reaches the intended audience.

question: Which of the following should be done FIRST when deciding to allow access to the information processing facility of an enterprise to a new external party?

justification.A: A contract language review is part of the risk assessment.
justification.B: A risk assessment identifies the risk involved in allowing access to an external party and the required controls.
justification.C: The exposure factor is part of the risk assessment.
justification.D: Vendor due diligence is part of the risk assessment.

question: An enterprise has a network of suppliers that it allows to remotely access an important database that contains critical supply chain data. What is the BEST control to ensure that the individual supplier representatives who have access to the system do not improperly access or modify information within this system?

justification.A: User access rights limit the access and rights that users have to a network, file system or database once they have been authenticated.
justification.B: Biometric access controls is a method of user access control that manages user access to an overall system, not generally to a specific set of files or records.
justification.C: Password authentication controls access but not rights once the system is accessed.
justification.D: Two-factor authentication controls access but not rights once the system is accessed.

question: Which of the following aspects is MOST important to include in the service level agreement to promote resolution of operational issues with a cloud computing vendor?

justification.A: The court of jurisdiction may be defined in the agreement, and in fact may be a benefit or a detriment to a satisfactory solution of operational issues, but seeking court remedies is generally costly and time-consuming and is not the best way to resolve operational issues with a vendor.
justification.B: A process description has a minimal impact on issue resolution.
justification.C: Audits may help identify and determine the nature of issues but by themselves will not help resolve them.
justification.D: When issues arise with cloud vendors, it is most important to identify ownership responsibility. This will promptly determine the next action to be taken for follow-up.

question: When securing wireless access points, which of the following controls would BEST assure confidentiality?

options.B: Not broadcasting the service set identifier
