options.D: Enforcing a virtual private network over wireless

justification.A: A wireless intrusion prevention system is a detective system and would not prevent wireless sniffing.
justification.B: Not broadcasting the service set identifier does not reduce the risk of wireless packets being captured.
justification.C: Wired equivalent privacy authentication is known to be weak and does not protect individual confidentiality.
justification.D: Enforcing a virtual private network over wireless is the best option to enforce strong authentication and encryption of the sessions.

question: Senior management is reluctant to budget for the acquisition of an intrusion prevention system. The chief information security officer should do which of the following activities?

options.A: Develop and present a business case for the project.
options.B: Seek the support of the users and information asset custodians.
options.C: Invite the vendor for a proof-of-concept demonstration.
options.D: Organize security awareness training for management.

justification.A: Senior management needs to understand the link between the acquisition of an intrusion prevention system (IPS) and the enterprise's business objectives. A business case is the best way to present this information.
justification.B: Stakeholder buy-in is an important part of the acquisition and implementation process, but senior management needs to see the value of budgeting for the purchase before moving ahead and making approvals.
justification.C: Senior managers probably believe that the IPS will do what it promises, but they are usually not tech-savvy. A proof-of-concept will demonstrate the functional features but may not be able to provide the understanding for senior management to approve the purchase.
justification.D: Security awareness training may provide some insight into the value of security tools in general, but the decision to allocate funds for an IPS will be made only on the basis of the specific value that the IPS provides.

question: Which of the following would PRIMARILY provide the potential for users to bypass a form-based authentication mechanism in an application with a back-end database?

options.A: A weak password of six characters
options.C: A session time-out of long duration
options.D: Lack of an account lockout after multiple wrong attempts

justification.A: Weak passwords can make it easy to access the application, but there is no bypass of authentication.
justification.B: Although structured query language injection is well understood and preventable, it still is a significant security risk for many enterprises writing code. Using SQL injection, one can pass SQL statements in a manner that bypasses the logon page and allows access to the application.
justification.C: Long time-out duration is not relevant to the authentication mechanism.
justification.D: Because the authentication mechanism is bypassed, account lockout is not initiated.

question: From a security perspective, which of the following is the MOST important step when an employee is transferred to a different function?

options.C: Conducting specific training for the new role
options.D: Knowledge of security weaknesses in the previous department

justification.A: When an employee is transferred from one function to another, it is very important to review and update the logical access rights to ensure that any access no longer needed is removed and appropriate access for the new position is granted.
justification.B: Assigning new security responsibilities may not be required.
justification.C: Training for a new role has no direct security implications.
justification.D: Having knowledge of security weaknesses in the previous department is not relevant.

question: Which of the following is the BEST way to erase confidential information stored on magnetic tapes?

justification.A: Performing a low-level format may be adequate but is a slow process, and with the right tools, data can still be recovered.
justification.B: Rewriting with zeros will not overwrite information located in the disk slack space.
justification.C: Burning destroys the tapes and does not allow their reuse.
justification.D: Degaussing the magnetic tapes would quickly dispose of all information because the magnetic domains are thoroughly scrambled and would not allow reuse.

question: For which of the following purposes would ethical hacking MOST likely be used?

options.A: a process resiliency test at an alternate site.
options.C: a control assessment of legacy applications.
options.D: a final check in a cyberattack recovery process.

justification.A: It is not common to conduct ethical hacking as part of disaster recovery testing at an alternate site.
justification.B: Substantive testing involves obtaining audit evidence on the completeness, accuracy or existence of activities or transactions during the audit period. Ethical hacking would not be used as a substitute for substantive testing.
justification.C: The problem with legacy applications is that there is typically not enough documentation to study their functionalities, including security controls. To assess control effectiveness, ethical hacking could be a more efficient way to find out weaknesses than reviewing program code.
justification.D: It is not necessarily a recommended practice to engage in ethical hacking in the last phase of a system recovery process after a cyberattack.

question: A contract has just been signed with a new vendor to manage IT support services. Which of the following tasks should the information security manager ensure is performed NEXT?

options.D: Have the vendor sign a nondisclosure agreement.

justification.A: Once the contract is signed, the security manager should ensure that continuous vendor monitoring is established and operational. This control will help identify and provide alerts on security events and minimize potential losses.
justification.B: The reporting relationships are defined prior to the contract being signed.
justification.C: The service level agreement is part of the contract.
justification.D: Nondisclosure agreements are signed prior to entering contract discussions.

question: Which of the following will be MOST important in calculating accurate return on investment in information security?

options.A: Excluding qualitative risk for accuracy in calculated figures
options.B: Establishing processes to ensure cost reductions
options.D: Treating security investment as a profit center

justification.A: If something is an important risk factor, an attempt should be made to quantify it even though it may not be highly accurate.
justification.B: Establishing processes to ensure cost reductions is not relevant to calculating return on investment (ROI).
justification.C: There must be consistency in metrics in order to have reasonably accurate and consistent results. In assessing security risk, it is not a good idea to simply exclude qualitative risk because of the difficulties in measurement.
justification.D: Whether security investment is treated as a profit center does not affect ROI calculations.

question: The director of auditing has recommended a specific information security monitoring solution to the information security manager. What should the information security manager do FIRST?

options.A: Obtain comparative pricing bids and complete the transaction with the vendor offering the best deal.
options.B: Add the purchase to the budget during the next budget preparation cycle to account for costs.
options.C: Perform an assessment to determine correlation with business goals and objectives.
options.D: Form a project team to plan the implementation.

justification.A: Comparative pricing bids and completing the transaction with the vendor offering the best deal is not necessary until a determination has been made regarding whether the product fits the goals and objectives of business.
justification.B: Adding the purchase to the budget is not necessary until a determination has been made regarding whether the product fits the goals and objectives of business.
justification.C: An assessment must be made first to determine that the proposed solution is aligned with business goals and objectives.
justification.D: Forming a project team for implementation is not necessary until a determination has been made regarding whether the product fits the goals and objectives of business.

question: When setting up an information classification scheme, the role of the information owner is to:

options.A: ensure that all data on an information system are protected according to the classification policy.
options.B: determine the classification of information across the information owner's scope of responsibility.
options.C: identify all information that requires backup according to its criticality and classification.
options.D: delegate the classification of information to responsible information custodians.

justification.A: The information system owner is responsible for protecting data on an information system according to the information security policy and the mandate and classification of the information. The classification would have been set up earlier.
justification.B: The information owner must determine the classification of information across the role's scope of responsibility and ensure that information is classified consistently.
justification.C: Identification of all information that requires backup according to classification will happen after the information classification scheme has been set up. Ensuring backup of data is the role of the information custodian and operations group.
justification.D: The information owner may delegate the classification to another responsible manager however this is not the advised role in setting up the classification scheme.

question: The formal declaration of organizational information security goals and objectives should be found in the:

justification.A: Security procedures are usually detailed as step-by-step actions to ensure that activities meet a given standard and cannot be considered as a formal declaration of organizational information security goals.
justification.B: Security principles are not always enterprise-specific and cannot be considered as a formal declaration of organizational information security goals.
justification.C: An employee code of conduct is a declaration of procedural requirements that may encompass more guidance than information security.
justification.D: The information security policy is management's formal declaration of security goals and objectives.

question: Which of the following is the MOST effective approach to identify events that may affect information security across a large multinational enterprise?

options.A: Review internal and external audits to indicate anomalies.
options.B: Ensure that intrusion detection sensors are widely deployed.
options.C: Develop communication channels throughout the enterprise.

justification.A: Audits are performed periodically, and a number of events can occur between audits that might not be detected and responded to in a timely manner.
justification.B: Intrusion detection sensors are useful in detecting intrusion events but not other types of events.
justification.C: Good communication channels can provide timely reporting of events across a large enterprise and provide channels for dissemination of security information.
justification.D: Enterprise-wide security reviews are an enormous task and will be, at best, periodic; therefore, they are an ineffective approach in providing timely information on events.

question: During an audit, an information security manager discovered that sales representatives were sending sensitive customer information through email messages. Which of the following is the BEST course of action to address the issue?

options.A: Review the finding with the sales manager to evaluate the risk and impact.
options.B: Report the issue to senior management immediately.
options.C: Request that the sales representatives stop emailing sensitive information.
options.D: Provide security awareness training to the sales representatives.

justification.A: It is always good practice to engage the management of the business unit when addressing security threats and risk. The input from business unit management is critical in formulating the next step.
justification.B: The issue should not be escalated until gaining an understanding of the risk and business issues from the business unit manager.
justification.C: Asking the representatives to stop sending sensitive information can be a temporary remediation but does not solve the underlying problem.
justification.D: Awareness training may help but does not resolve the problem.

question: Which of the following is BEST used to define minimum requirements for database security settings?

justification.A: Procedures determine the steps, not the configuration requirements.
justification.B: Guidelines are not enforceable.
justification.C: Baselines set the minimum security controls required for safeguarding an IT system based on its identified needs for confidentiality, integrity and availability protection.
justification.D: Policies determine direction but not detailed configurations.

question: Who would be the PRIMARY user of metrics regarding the number of email messages quarantined due to virus infection versus the number of infected email messages that were not caught?

justification.A: Metrics support decisions. Knowing the number of email messages blocked due to viruses would not on its own be an actionable piece of information for the steering committee.
justification.B: The board of directors would have no use for the information.
justification.C: IT managers would be interested, but it would not be in their purview to address the issue.
justification.D: Information regarding the effectiveness of the current email antivirus control is most useful to the information security manager and staff because they can use the information to initiate an investigation to determine why the control is not performing as expected and to determine whether there are other factors contributing to the failure of the control. When these determinations are made, the information security manager can use these metrics, along with data collected during the investigation, to support decisions to alter processes or to (or change) the controls in place.

question: What is the MOST important item to be included in an information security policy?

options.A: The definition of roles and responsibilities
options.B: The scope of the security program
options.C: The key objectives of the security program
options.D: Reference to procedures and standards of the security program

justification.A: The definition of roles and responsibilities is part of implementing an information security governance framework.
justification.B: The scope of the security program should be defined in the charter of the information security program.
justification.C: Stating the objectives of the security program is the most important element to ensure alignment with business goals.
justification.D: Reference to standards that interpret the policy may be included, but the multitude of procedures controlled by those standards would not normally be referenced.

question: The corporate information security policy should:

options.B: address the process for communicating a violation.
options.C: be straightforward and easy to understand.
options.D: be customized to specific target audiences.

justification.A: Information security policies are high level documents and will not address network vulnerabilities or functional issues directly.
justification.B: Information security policies are high-level documents and do not address the process for communicating a violation.
justification.C: As high-level statements, information security policies should be straightforward and easy to understand.
justification.D: As policies, information security policies should provide a uniform message to all groups and user roles.

question: Requiring all employees and contractors to meet personnel security/suitability requirements commensurate with their position's sensitivity level and subject to personnel screening is an example of a security:

justification.A: A security policy is a general statement to define management objectives with respect to security.
justification.B: The security strategy is the plan to achieve security objectives and it does not provide guidance at the employee/contractor level.
justification.C: Guidelines are optional actions and helpful narrative and do not provide guidance at the employee/contractor level.
justification.D: A security baseline is a set of minimum security requirements that is acceptable to an enterprise and it does not provide guidance at the employee/contractor level.

question: The MOST important aspect in establishing good information security policies is to ensure that they:

options.A: have the consensus of all concerned groups.
options.B: are easy to access by all employees.
options.D: have been approved by the internal audit department.

justification.A: Having the consensus of all concerned groups is desirable but is not the most important aspect of good policies, which express the intent and direction of senior management.
justification.B: Easy availability of policies is important but not an indicator of good information security content and guidance.
justification.C: Policies should reflect the intent and direction of senior management, and this is the most important aspect of establishing good information security policies.
justification.D: The internal audit department tests compliance with policy, but it does not write the policies.

question: Which of the following choices would provide the BEST measure of the effectiveness of the security strategy?

options.B: Countermeasures existing for all known threats
options.C: Losses consistent with annual loss expectations
options.D: The extent to which control objectives are met

justification.A: Minimizing risk is not the objective. The objective is achieving control objectives and thereby achieving acceptable risk levels. Risk reduction beyond the acceptable level is likely to not be cost-effective and to be a waste of resources.
justification.B: There are some threats for which no countermeasures exist (e.g., comet strikes).
justification.C: The extent of losses is not a reliable indication of the effectiveness of the strategy. Losses may or may not exceed expectations for a variety of reasons and relate to impacts rather than to risk levels.
justification.D: Control objectives are developed to achieve acceptable levels of risk. To the extent those levels are achieved, control objectives are a good measure of the effectiveness of the strategy.

question: "Sensitive data must be protected to prevent loss, theft, unauthorized access and/or unauthorized disclosure" is a statement that would MOST likely be found in a:

justification.A: A guideline is a suggested action that is not mandatory.
justification.B: A policy is a principle that is used to set direction in an enterprise. It can be a course of action to steer and influence decisions. The wording of the policy must make the course of action mandatory and it must set the direction.
justification.C: A procedure is a particular way of accomplishing something.
justification.D: A standard sets the allowable boundaries for people, processes and technologies that must be met to meet the intent of the policy.

question: Which of the following are likely to be updated MOST frequently?

options.B: Standards for password length and complexity
options.D: Standards for document retention and destruction

justification.A: Procedures, especially with regard to the hardening of operating systems, will be subject to constant change; as operating systems change and evolve, the procedures for hardening will have to keep pace.
justification.B: Standards should generally be more static and less subject to frequent change.
justification.C: Well-conceived, mature policies will rarely require change.
justification.D: Standards regarding document retention and destruction will rarely need to be changed.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important information to include in an information security standard?

justification.A: The creation date is not that important.
justification.B: The name of the author is not that important.
justification.C: The initial draft date is not that important.
justification.D: The last review date confirms the currency of the standard, affirming that management has reviewed the standard to ensure that nothing in the environment has changed that would necessitate an update to the standard.

question: To improve the security of an enterprise's human resources system, an information security manager was presented with a choice to either implement an additional packet filtering firewall OR a heuristics-based intrusion detection system. How should the security manager with a limited budget choose between the two technologies?

justification.A: Risk analysis identifies the risk and treatment options.
justification.B: A business impact analysis identifies the impact from the loss of systems or enterprise functions.
justification.C: Return on investment analysis compares the magnitude and timing of investment gains directly with the magnitude and timing of investment costs.
justification.D: Cost-benefit analysis measures the cost of a safeguard versus the benefit it provides and includes risk assessment. The cost of a control should not exceed the benefit to be derived from it. The degree of control employed is a matter of good business judgment.

question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY reason to change policies during program development?

options.A: The policies must comply with new regulatory and legal mandates.
options.B: Appropriate security baselines are no longer set in the policies.
options.C: The policies no longer reflect management intent and direction.

justification.A: Regulatory requirements typically are better addressed with standards and procedures than with high-level policies.
justification.B: Standards set security baselines, not policies.
justification.C: Policies must reflect management intent and direction. Policies should be changed only when management determines that there is a need to address new business requirements.
justification.D: Employees not abiding by policies is a compliance and enforcement issue rather than a reason to change the policies.

question: Which of the following should be included in a good privacy statement?

options.A: A notification of liability on accuracy of information
options.B: A notification that information will be encrypted
options.C: A statement of what the company will do with information it collects
options.D: A description of the information classification process

justification.A: A notification of liability on accuracy of information should be located in the website's disclaimer.
justification.B: Although encryption may be applied, this is not generally disclosed.
justification.C: Most privacy laws and regulations require disclosure on how information will be used.
justification.D: Information classification is unrelated to privacy statements and would be contained in a separate policy.

question: Which of the following will require the MOST effort when supporting an operational information security program?

options.B: Modifying policies to address changing technologies
options.C: Writing additional policies to address new regulations
options.D: Drafting standards to address regional differences

justification.A: When an information security program is operational, few changes to policies or standards will be needed. Procedures, however, are designed at a more granular level and will require reasonably frequent modification. Because procedures are more detailed and can be technology specific, there are generally far more procedures than standards or policies. Consequently, review and modification of procedures will consume the majority of effort.
justification.B: While technology does change, it is relatively rare for a technology shift to be so disruptive as to require a modification of policy. Most technological changes should be addressed at lower levels (e.g., in standards or procedures).
justification.C: New regulations may require the creation of a new policy, but this does not happen nearly as often or consume as much time in an operational program as the review and modification of procedures.
justification.D: Global enterprises may need to customize policy through the use of regional standards, but an operational program will already have most of these standards in place. Even where they need to be drafted, the level of effort required to customize policy by region is less than what will be needed to review and modify the vast body of procedures that change more frequently.

question: When an enterprise is setting up a relationship with a third-party IT service provider, which of the following is one of the MOST important topics to include in the contract from a security standpoint?

options.B: Use of a two-factor authentication system
options.C: Existence of an alternate hot site in case of business disruption
options.D: Compliance with the enterprise's information security requirements

justification.A: Requiring compliance only with this security standard does not guarantee that a service provider complies with the enterprise's security requirements.
justification.B: The requirement to use a specific kind of control methodology is not usually stated in the contract with third-party service providers.
justification.C: The requirement for a hot site is not usually stated in the contract with third-party service providers.
justification.D: From a security standpoint, compliance with the enterprise's information security requirements is one of the most important topics that should be included in the contract with third-party service provider.

question: A newly hired information security manager notes that existing information security practices and procedures appear ad hoc. Based on this observation, the next action should be to:

options.A: assess the commitment of senior management to the program.
options.B: assess the maturity level of the enterprise.

justification.A: While management may not be exercising due care, it is concerned enough to engage a new information security manager. Assessing the commitment of senior management will not address the immediate concern of ad hoc practices and procedures.
justification.B: It is evident from the initial review that maturity is very low and efforts required for a complete assessment are not warranted. It may be better to address the immediate problem of ad hoc practices and procedures.
justification.C: The absence of current, effective standards is a concern that must be addressed promptly.
justification.D: It is apparent that risk management is not being practiced; establishing an effective program will take time. A more prudent initial activity is to implement basic controls.

question: Which of the following is an advantage of a centralized information security organizational structure?

options.A: It is easier to promote security awareness.
options.B: It is easier to manage and control.
options.C: It is more responsive to business unit needs.
options.D: It provides a faster turnaround for security requests.

justification.A: Decentralization allows the use of field security personnel as security missionaries or ambassadors to spread the security awareness message.
justification.B: It is easier to manage and control a centralized structure. Promoting security awareness is an advantage of decentralization.
justification.C: Decentralized operations allow security administrators to be more responsive.
justification.D: Being close to the business allows decentralized security administrators to achieve a faster turnaround than that achieved in a centralized operation.

question: Senior management has expressed some concern about the effectiveness of the information security program. What can the information security manager do to gain the support of senior management for the program?

options.A: Rebuild the program based on a recognized, auditable standard.
options.B: Calculate the cost-benefit analysis of the existing controls that are in place.
options.C: Interview senior managers to address their concerns with the program.
options.D: Present a report from the steering committee supporting the program.

justification.A: The key to gaining support from senior management is understanding its concerns and making sure that those concerns are addressed. Replacing the entire program as a response to general concerns would not be appropriate without more information.
justification.B: A cost-benefit analysis of controls demonstrates that the controls that have been put in place were preferable to alternative methods of risk treatment, but this evidence does not address the question of overall program effectiveness.
justification.C: It is not uncommon for senior managers to have concerns. An effective information security manager will discuss these concerns and make changes as needed to address them.
justification.D: The steering committee generally reports to senior management, so if senior managers express concern regarding the effectiveness of the program, the concern may be directed in part at the steering committee.

question: What is the PRIMARY purpose of installing an intrusion detection system?

options.A: To identify weaknesses in network security
options.B: To identify patterns of suspicious logon attempts
options.C: To identify how an attack was launched on the network
options.D: To identify potential attacks on the internal network

justification.A: An intrusion detection system is not designed to identify weaknesses in network security.
justification.B: An intrusion detection system is not designed to identify patterns of suspicious logon attempts.
justification.C: Identifying how an attack was launched is secondary.
justification.D: The most important function of an intrusion detection system is to identify potential attacks on the network.

question: What is the GREATEST benefit of decentralized security management?

options.A: Reduction of the total cost of ownership
options.B: Improved compliance with organizational policies and standards
options.C: Better alignment of security with business needs

justification.A: Reduction of the total cost of ownership is a benefit of centralized security management.
justification.B: Improved compliance is a benefit of centralized security management.
justification.C: Better alignment of security with business needs is the only answer that fits because the other choices are benefits of centralized security management.
justification.D: Easier administration is a benefit of centralized security management.

question: Which of the following is one of the BEST metrics an information security manager can employ to effectively evaluate the results of a security program?

options.C: Percent of compliance with the security policy
options.D: Reduction in the number of reported security incidents

justification.A: Number of controls implemented does not have a direct relationship with the results of a security program.
justification.B: Control objectives are directly related to business objectives; therefore, they would be the best metrics.
justification.C: Percent in compliance with the security policy is a useful metric but says nothing about achieving control objectives.
justification.D: A reduction in the number of security incidents has no direct bearing on whether control objectives are being achieved.

question: Which of the following indicators is MOST likely to be of strategic value?

options.A: Number of users with privileged access

justification.A: The number of users with privileged access, if excessive, can pose unnecessary risk but is more of an operational metric.
justification.B: Trends in incident frequency will show whether the information security program is improving and heading in the right direction.
justification.C: Network downtime is a relevant operational metric in terms of service level agreements but, without trends over time, it is not a useful strategic metric.
justification.D: Vulnerability scans are an operational metric.

question: Obtaining another party's public key is required to initiate which of the following activities?

justification.A: Authorization is not a public key infrastructure function.
justification.B: A private key is used for signing.
justification.C: The counterparty's public key is used for authentication.
justification.D: The private key is used for nonrepudiation.

question: Which one of the following combinations offers the STRONGEST encryption and authentication method for 802.11 wireless networks?

options.A: Wired equivalent privacy with 128-bit pre-shared key authentication
options.B: Temporal Key Integrity Protocol-Message Integrity Check with the RC4 cipher
options.C: Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2) and pre-shared key authentication

justification.A: Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) with 128-bit pre-shared key authentication can be easily cracked with open source tools. WEP is easily compromised and is no longer recommended for secure wireless networks.
justification.B: Temporal Key Integrity Protocol-Message Integrity Check (TKIP-MIC) with the RC4 cipher is not as strong as WPA2 with 802.1x authentication.
justification.C: Wi-Fi Protected Access 2 (WPA2) with pre-shared keys uses the strongest level of encryption, but the authentication is more easily compromised.
justification.D: WPA2 and 802.1x authentication is the strongest form of wireless authentication currently available. WPA2 combined with 802.1x forces the user to authenticate using strong Advanced Encryption Standard encryption.

question: Which one of the following types of detection is NECESSARY to mitigate a denial or distributed denial-of-service attack?

justification.A: Signature-based detection cannot react to a distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attack because it does not have any insight into increases in traffic levels.
justification.B: Deep packet inspection allows a protocol to be inspected and is not related to denial-of-service (DoS) attacks.
justification.C: Virus detection would have no effect on DDoS detection or mitigation.
justification.D: Anomaly-based detection establishes normal traffic patterns and then detects any deviation from that baseline. Traffic baselines are greatly exceeded when under a DDoS attack and are quickly identified by anomaly-based detection.

question: The MOST effective technical approach to mitigate the risk of confidential information being disclosed in outgoing email attachments is to implement:

justification.A: Content filtering provides the ability to examine the content of attachments and prevent information containing certain words or phrases, or of certain identifiable classifications, from being sent out of the enterprise.
justification.B: Data classification helps identify the material that should not be transmitted via email attachments but by itself will not prevent it.
justification.C: Information security awareness training also helps limit confidential material from being disclosed via email as long as personnel are aware of what information should not be exposed and willingly comply with the requirements, but it is not as effective as outgoing content filtering.
justification.D: Encrypting all attachments is not effective because it does not limit the content and may actually obscure confidential information contained in the email.

question: An enterprise is planning to deliver subscription-based educational services to customers online that will require customers to log in with their user IDs and passwords. Which of the following is the BEST method to validate passwords entered by a customer before access to educational resources is granted?

justification.A: Encryption is the application of an algorithm that converts the plaintext password to the encrypted form, but using encrypted passwords only they be decrypted for authentication—this would expose the actual password. Also, the authentication mechanism would need to have access to the encryption key in order to decrypt the password for authentication. This would allow anyone with the appropriate access to the server to decrypt user passwords, which is not typically acceptable and is not a secure practice.
justification.B: Content filtering is not a component of password validation.
justification.C: Database hardening helps in enhancing the security of a database but does not assist with password validation.
justification.D: Hashing refers to a one-way algorithm that always creates the same output if applied to the same input. When hashing passwords, only the password's hash value (output) is stored, not the actual password (input). When a user logs in and enters the password, the hash is applied to the password by the authentication mechanism and compared to the stored hash. If the hash matches, then access is granted. The actual password cannot be derived from the hash (because it is a one-way algorithm), so there is no chance of the password being compromised from the hash values stored on the server.

question: Integrating a number of different activities in the development of an information security infrastructure is BEST achieved by developing:

justification.A: A business plan may address some issues of integrating activities, but that is not its main purpose.
justification.B: An architecture allows different activities to be integrated under one design authority.
justification.C: Requirements do not generally address integration.
justification.D: Specifications do not address integration.

question: After deciding to acquire a security information and event management system, it is MOST important for the information security manager to:

options.A: perform a comparative analysis of available systems.
options.B: develop a comprehensive business case for the system.
options.C: use the enterprise's existing acquisition process.
options.D: ensure that there is adequate network capacity for the system.

justification.A: A comparative analysis should have been accomplished prior to the decision to purchase.
justification.B: Development of a business case should have been accomplished prior to the decision to purchase.
justification.C: The information security manager should always use existing enterprise practices and processes whenever possible to minimize potential issues with other departments.
justification.D: Ensuring adequate capacity should have been accomplished prior to the decision to purchase.

question: Which of the following is MOST important in the development of information security policies?

options.B: Using modular design for easier maintenance

justification.A: A framework will not be effective without including the management intent and direction provided by policies.
justification.B: While using a modular design should be a key consideration, it is not as important as considering stakeholder input. Stakeholder input not only promotes policy completeness, it also facilitates stakeholder buy-in.
justification.C: Prevailing industry standards are important but may not be appropriate or suitable to address unique or specific issues in an enterprise.
justification.D: The primary stakeholders in policies are management, and policies are the primary governance tool employed in an enterprise; therefore, the policies must reflect management intent and direction.

question: An enterprise has commissioned an information security expert to perform network penetration testing and has provided the expert with information about the infrastructure to be tested. The benefit of this approach is:

options.A: more time is devoted to exploitation than to fingerprinting and discovery.
options.B: this accurately simulates an external hacking attempt.
options.C: the ability to exploit Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol vulnerabilities.
options.D: the elimination of the need for penetration testing tools.

justification.A: When information is provided to the penetration tester (white box testing), less time is spent on discovering and understanding the target to be penetrated.
justification.B: A black box approach, where no information is provided, better simulates an actual hacking attempt.
justification.C: Both white box and black box approaches could exploit Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol vulnerabilities.
justification.D: Both white box and black box approaches would require use of penetration testing tools.

question: Which of the following is the BEST way to verify that all critical production servers are utilizing up-to-date virus signature files?

options.A: Verify the date that signature files were last pushed out.
options.B: Use a recently identified benign virus to test if it is quarantined.
options.C: Research the most recent signature file and compare to the console.
options.D: Check a sample of servers that the signature files are current.

justification.A: The fact that an update was pushed out to a server does not guarantee that it was properly loaded onto that server.
justification.B: Personnel should never release a virus, no matter how benign.
justification.C: Checking the vendor information to the management console would still not indicate whether the file was properly loaded on the server.
justification.D: The only accurate way to check the signature files is to look at a sample of servers.

question: An enterprise has recently developed and approved an access control policy. Which of the following will be MOST effective in communicating the access control policy to the employees?

options.A: Requiring employees to formally acknowledge receipt of the policy
options.B: Integrating security requirements into job descriptions
options.C: Making the policy available on the intranet
options.D: Implementing an annual retreat for employees on information security

justification.A: Requiring employees to formally acknowledge receipt of the policy does not guarantee that the policy has been read or understood but establishes employee acknowledgment of the existence of the new policy. Each communication should identify a point of contact for follow-up questions.
justification.B: Current employees do not necessarily reread job descriptions that would contain the new policy.
justification.C: Making the policy available on the intranet does not ensure that the document has been read, nor does it create an audit trail that establishes that employees have been made aware of the policy.
justification.D: An annual event may not be timely and may not rectify significant gaps in awareness.

question: A security baseline can BEST be used for:

justification.A: The stability of an environment is not necessarily related to baselines; the application of a security baseline can sometimes even destabilize an environment by conflicting with existing software.
justification.B: A security baseline establishes a uniform-security standard to be applied across similar systems.
justification.C: A baseline does not prioritize security objectives.
justification.D: Baselines are established as the result of a policy; they are not part of the policy development.

question: The newly appointed chief information security officer (CISO) of a pharmaceutical company is given the task of creating information security procedures for all departments in the company. Which one of the following groups should the CISO initially approach to write the procedures?

justification.A: The legal department is not typically involved in writing procedures, except for its own procedures.
justification.B: End users are not typically involved in writing procedures.
justification.C: Senior management would not be directly involved in the writing of security procedures.
justification.D: The operations group has firsthand knowledge of organizational processes and responsibilities and should ensure that all procedures that are written are functionally sound.

question: Which of the following is the MOST appropriate control to address compliance with specific regulatory requirements?

justification.A: Policies are a statement of management intent, expectations and direction and should not address the specifics of regulatory compliance.
justification.B: Standards set the allowable boundaries for technologies, procedures and practices and thus are the appropriate documentation to define compliance requirements.
justification.C: Procedures are developed in order to provide instruction for meeting standards but cannot be developed without established standards.
justification.D: Guidelines are not mandatory and will not normally address issues of regulatory compliance.

question: Which of the following is the MOST effective method to enhance information security awareness?

options.A: Timely emails that address actual security threats
options.B: Security training from specialized external experts for key IT personnel
options.D: General online security awareness training for all staff

justification.A: Email is not a strong communication medium to enhance information security awareness.
justification.B: Training for IT personnel is important, but information security awareness training needs to be provided to all employees.
justification.C: Role-based training that includes simulation of actual information security incidents is the most effective method to teach employees how their specific function can impact information security.
justification.D: Well-developed general awareness training can be an acceptable method to enhance information security awareness if resources are not available for role-specific training, but it is not typically as effective.

question: In a mature enterprise, it would be expected that the security baseline could be approximated by which of the following?

justification.A: Policies, as a statement of management intent and direction, will only indicate the security baseline in general sense.
justification.B: Enterprise architecture may or may not provide an indication of some of the controls implemented.
justification.C: The control objectives, when achieved, set the security baselines.
justification.D: Compliance requirements will indicate some of the controls required indicative of what the baseline should be but only in the areas related to specific regulations.

question: Which one of the following phases of the application development life cycle for in-house development represents the BEST opportunity for an information security manager to influence the outcome of the development effort?

options.A: System design for a new application

justification.A: The design phase helps determine how the requirements will be implemented; however, if an information security manager first becomes involved in the design phase, the manager will likely find that influencing the outcome of the development effort will be more difficult.
justification.B: The user acceptance testing and sign-off phase is too late in the life cycle to effectively influence the outcome.
justification.C: An information security manager should be involved in the earliest phase of the application development life cycle to effectively influence the outcome of the development effort. Of the choices listed, the requirements gathering and analysis phase represents the earliest opportunity for an information security manager to have such influence. During this phase, both functional and nonfunctional requirements, including security, should be considered.
justification.D: The implementation phase is too late in the life cycle to effectively influence the outcome.

question: An information security manager has instructed a system database administrator to implement native database auditing in order to meet regulatory requirements for privileged user monitoring. Which of the following is the PRIMARY reason that the database administrator would be concerned? Native database auditing:

justification.A: Interference with policy-driven event logging is a potential concern but secondary to performance impact.
justification.B: Many database products come with a native audit log function. Although it can be easily activated, there is a risk that it may negatively impact the performance of the database.
justification.C: The need to develop supplementary tools is a potential concern but secondary to performance impact.
justification.D: Impaired flexibility in configuration management is not an issue.

question: Controls that fail closed (secure) will present a risk to:

justification.A: The blocked access will not generally impact confidentiality.
justification.B: The blocked access will not generally impact integrity.
justification.C: The blocked access will not generally impact authenticity.
justification.D: A control (such as a firewall) that fails in a closed condition will typically prevent access to resources behind it, thus impacting availability.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important aspect that needs to be considered from a security perspective when payroll processes are outsourced to an external service provider?

options.A: A cost-benefit analysis has been completed.
options.C: The service provider ensures a secure data transfer.
options.D: No significant security incident occurred at the service provider

justification.A: A cost-benefit analysis should be undertaken from a business perspective but not from a security perspective.
justification.B: Applicable privacy requirements may be a matter of law or policy and will require consideration when outsourcing processes that involve personal information.
justification.C: When data are transferred, it may be necessary to ensure data security, but there are many other privacy and security issues to consider.
justification.D: Past incidents may not reflect the current security posture of the service provider, nor do they reflect applicable security requirements.

question: When initially establishing an information security program, it is MOST important that managers:

options.A: examine and understand the culture within the enterprise.
options.B: analyze and understand the control system of the enterprise.
options.C: identify and evaluate the overall risk exposure of the enterprise.
options.D: examine and assess the security resources of the enterprise.

justification.A: Examining and understanding the culture within the enterprise is an important step in the overall evaluation process.
justification.B: Analyzing and understanding the control system is an essential step to determine what risk is addressed and what control objectives are currently in place.
justification.C: Identifying and evaluating the overall risk is most important, because it includes the other three elements, in addition to others.
justification.D: Examining and assessing security resources is important information in determining and evaluating overall risk and exposure of an enterprise.

question: The requirement for due diligence is MOST closely associated with which of the following?

justification.A: The right to audit is an important consideration when evaluating an enterprise but is not as closely related to the concept of due diligence.
justification.B: Service level agreements are an important consideration when evaluating an enterprise but are not as closely related to the concept of due diligence.
justification.C: The standard of care is most closely related to due diligence. It is based on the legal notion of the steps that would be taken by a person of similar competency in similar circumstances.
justification.D: Periodic security reviews is not as closely related to due diligence.

question: Which one of the following factors affects the extent to which controls should be layered?

options.D: Controls that fail in a closed condition

justification.A: A negative impact on productivity could indicate that controls may be too restrictive, but it is not a consideration for layering.
justification.B: Common failure modes in existing controls must be addressed by adding or modifying controls so they fail under different conditions. This is done to manage the aggregate risk of total control failure.
justification.C: Excessive maintenance costs will probably increase and not be addressed by layering additional controls.
justification.D: Excessive maintenance costs will probably increase and not be addressed by layering additional controls.

question: When recommending a control to protect enterprise applications against structured query language injection, the information security manager is MOST likely to suggest

options.B: consolidating multiple sites into a single portal.
options.D: using Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) in place of HTTP.

justification.A: Hardening of web servers does not reduce this type of vulnerability.
justification.B: Consolidating multiple sites into a single portal does not reduce this type of vulnerability.
justification.C: Implementing secure coding standards and peer review as part of the enterprise's system development life cycle (SDLC) are controls that address structured query language injection.
justification.D: Using Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure (HTTPS) instead of HTTP does not reduce this type of vulnerability.

question: What is the most significant attribute of a good information security metric?

options.A: It is meaningful to the recipient.

justification.A: Information provided by metrics that are not meaningful to the recipient is of little value.
justification.B: Reliability and accuracy are important criteria for selecting information security metrics, but it must first be determined that the information provided helps recipients accomplish their tasks.
justification.C: The impact on productivity must be balanced against the usefulness of the metric; however, it is a valid consideration.
justification.D: Cost-effectiveness must be balanced against the usefulness of the metric; however, it is a valid consideration. Scalability of metrics—in most situations—is more of a nice-to-have criterion than a selection criterion.

question: Why is a certificate authority needed in a public key infrastructure?

options.A: It provides a proof of the integrity of data.
options.B: It prevents the denial of specific transactions.
options.C: It attests to the validity of a user's public key.
options.D: It stores a user's private key.

justification.A: The certificate authority (CA) does not provide proof of message integrity.
justification.B: Nonrepudiation prevents a party from denying that the party originated a specific transaction and is provided by a user's private key signing communication.
justification.C: The CA is a trusted third party that attests to the authenticity of a user's public key by digitally signing it with the CA's private key.
justification.D: A conventional CA does not store a user's private key.

question: In what circumstances should mandatory access controls be used?

options.A: When the enterprise has a high risk tolerance
options.B: When delegation of rights is contrary to policy
options.C: When the control policy specifies continuous oversight
options.D: When access is permitted, unless explicitly denied

justification.A: Mandatory access controls (MACs) are a restrictive control employed in situations of low risk tolerance.
justification.B: With MAC, the security policy is centrally controlled by a security policy administrator, and users do not have the ability to delegate rights.
justification.C: A requirement for continuous oversight is not related to MACs.
justification.D: MACs do not allow access as a default condition.

question: Information security policy development should PRIMARILY be based on:

justification.A: Absent a threat, vulnerabilities do not pose a risk. Vulnerability is defined as a weakness in the design, implementation, operation or internal control of a process that could expose the system to adverse impacts from threat events.
justification.B: Exposure is only important if there is a threat. Exposure is defined as the potential loss to an area due to the occurrence of an adverse event.
justification.C: Policies are developed in response to perceived threats. If there is no perceived threat, there is no need for a policy. A threat is defined as anything (e.g., object, substance, human) that is capable of acting against an asset in a manner that can result in harm.
justification.D: Impact is not an issue if no threat exists. The impact is generally quantified as a direct financial loss in the short term or an ultimate (indirect) financial loss in the long term.

question: What is the MOST likely reason that an organizational policy can be eliminated?

options.B: The policy is ignored by staff.
options.D: The policy is not required by regulatory requirements.

justification.A: If it is certain that there is no threat, then there is no risk and a policy is not needed to address it.
justification.B: Noncompliance is not a good reason to eliminate a policy.
justification.C: If the standards are obsolete, then they should be brought current, but that is not a reason to eliminate the policy.
justification.D: If there is a potential risk, then there is a reason to have the policy, independent of whether regulation mandates that particular control.

question: The IT department has been tasked with developing a new transaction processing system for online account management. At which stage should the information security department become involved?

justification.A: Involve the security department as early as possible. Security considerations will affect feasibility. Security that is added later in the process often is not nearly as effective as security that is considered from end to end.
justification.B: The requirements stage is too late in the process, and the introduction of security requirements will potentially cause delays or incur other costs that are neither budgeted nor anticipated by stakeholders.
justification.C: The design stage is too late in the process, and the introduction of security requirements will potentially cause delays or incur other costs that are neither budgeted nor anticipated by stakeholders.
justification.D: The user acceptance testing stage is too late in the process, and the introduction of security requirements will potentially cause delays or incur other costs that are neither budgeted nor anticipated by stakeholders.

question: Which of the following is an example of a corrective control?

options.A: Diverting incoming traffic as a response to a denial-of-service attack
options.C: Examining inbound network traffic for viruses

justification.A: Diverting incoming traffic helps correct the situation and, therefore, is a corrective control.
justification.B: Filtering network traffic is a preventive control.
justification.C: Examining inbound network traffic for viruses is a detective control.
justification.D: Logging inbound network traffic is a detective control.

question: What is the MAIN objective of integrating the information security process into the system development life cycle?

options.B: It ensures that appropriate controls are implemented.
options.D: It establishes the foundation for development or acquisition.

justification.A: Simply integrating information security processes into the system development life cycle (SDLC) will not ensure audit compliance; it is merely a piece of the compliance puzzle that must be reviewed by the auditor.
justification.B: Establishing information security processes at the front end of any development project and using the process at each stage of the SDLC ensures that the appropriate security controls are implemented, based on the review and assessment completed by security staff.
justification.C: The purpose of integrating the information security process at the front end of any SDLC project is to reduce the risk of delays or rework rather than to identify roles and responsibilities for information security in the project.
justification.D: The information security process should be performed at each phase of the SDLC to ensure that appropriate controls are in place. However, integration of information security does not establish the foundation for the make-versus-buy decision.

question: Which of the following is the MAIN reason for implementing a corporate information security education and awareness program?

options.A: To achieve commitment from the board and senior management
options.B: To assign roles and responsibility for information security
options.C: To establish a culture that is conducive to effective security
options.D: To meet information security policy and regulatory requirements

justification.A: Implementing such a program is an ongoing process that supports senior management's commitment to information security.
justification.B: Assigning roles and responsibilities for information security is achieved largely by implementing information security policies. However, to be effective, it is important that the policy be supported by a corporate information security education and awareness program.
justification.C: Education, training and awareness help in the dissemination of information on the necessity of information security and in building a conducive environment for secure and reliable business operations.
justification.D: The information security policy and regulatory requirements contribute content to an education and awareness program.

question: Which of the following would be the BEST indicator that an enterprise has good governance?

justification.A: While it is likely that good results on risk assessments will align with good governance, they are only indirectly correlated with good governance, and many other factors are involved such as industry sector, exposure, etc.
justification.B: A high score on the capability maturity model (CMM) scale is a good indicator of good governance.
justification.C: Audit reports generally deal with specifics of compliance and specific risk rather than overall governance.
justification.D: Loss history will be affected by many factors other than governance.

question: Which of the following activities is MOST effective for developing a data classification schema?

options.A: Classifying critical data based on protection levels
options.B: Classifying data based on the possibility of leakage
options.C: Aligning the schema with data leak prevention tools
options.D: Building awareness of the benefit of data classification

justification.A: Data protection levels are decided based on classification or business value.
justification.B: Data are classified on business value and not on the possibility of leakage. Protection of the data may well be based on the possibility of leakage.
justification.C: Aligning the schema with data leak prevention (DLP) tools may help while automating protection, but the data classification schema already has to exist for it to align with DLP.
justification.D: While developing a data classification schema, it is most important that all users are made aware of the need for accurate data classification to reduce the cost of overprotection and the risk of underprotection of information assets.

question: Which of the following choices is a MAJOR concern with using the database snapshot of the audit log function?

justification.A: Evidential capability increases if data are taken from a location that is close to the origination point. For database auditing, activation of a built-in log may be ideal. However, there is a trade-off. The more elaborate logging becomes, the slower the performance. It is important to strike a balance.
justification.B: If database recovery log is impaired, there is a chance that data integrity may be lost. However, it is unlikely that audit logging will impair the integrity of the database.
justification.C: Database replication functionality will control the consistency between database instances.
justification.D: It is difficult to judge whether configuration change will become complex as the result of audit log activation. It depends on many factors. Therefore, this is not the best option.

question: What is the PRIMARY goal of developing an information security program?

justification.A: The development of an information security program is usually seen as a manifestation of the information security strategy. Thus, the goal of developing the information security program is to implement the strategy.
justification.B: Optimizing resources can be achieved in an information security program once the program has been aligned to the strategy.
justification.C: Delivery of the metrics is a subset of strategic alignment with the information security program in an enterprise.
justification.D: Assurance of information security occurs upon the strategic alignment of the information security program.

question: An enterprise has decided to implement bring your own device (BYOD) for laptops and mobile phones. What should the information security manager focus on FIRST?

options.A: Advising against implementing BYOD because of a security risk
options.B: Preparing a business case for new security tools for BYOD
options.C: Updating the security awareness program to include BYOD
options.D: Determining an information security strategy for BYOD

justification.A: The enterprise has already made the decision to implement bring your own device (BYOD). The security manager's role is to identify and communicate the risk and determine how to implement this decision in the most secure way.
justification.B: A business case can be prepared if new tools are required for implementing BYOD; however, this requirement will be based on the security strategy.
justification.C: The security strategy must take into account BYOD before the security awareness program may be updated to include it.
justification.D: The information security manager should determine whether the existing strategy can accommodate BYOD and, if not, then what changes are needed. A risk assessment and other tools may be part of this process.

question: Decisions regarding information security are BEST supported by:

justification.A: A statistical analysis of metrics can be helpful but only if the underlying metrics are sound.
justification.B: Expert advice may be useful, but effective metrics are a better indication.
justification.C: Other enterprises would typically only provide some guidance, but decisions should be based on effective metrics.
justification.D: Effective metrics are essential to provide information needed to make decisions. Metrics are a quantifiable entity that allows the measurement of the achievement of a process goal.

question: Which of the following is the MOST effective method for ensuring that outsourced operations comply with the company's information security posture?

options.A: The vendor is provided with audit documentation.
options.B: A comprehensive contract is written with service level metrics and penalties.
options.C: Periodic onsite visits are made to the vendor's site.
options.D: An onsite audit and compliance review is performed.

justification.A: Audit documentation may not show whether the vendor meets the company's needs; the company needs to know the testing procedures.
justification.B: While comprehensive contracts set minimum service levels, contracts do not ensure that vendors will perform without confirming oversight.
justification.C: On-site visits to the vendor's site are not sufficient by themselves; they should be coupled with an audit approach to gauge information security compliance.
justification.D: Audits and compliance reviews are the most effective way to ensure compliance.

question: Why is public key infrastructure the preferred model when providing encryption keys to a large number of individuals?

options.B: It is more scalable than a symmetric key.
options.C: It is less costly to maintain than a symmetric key approach.
options.D: It provides greater encryption strength than a secret key model.

justification.A: Public key cryptography is computationally intensive due to the long key lengths required.
justification.B: Symmetric or secret key encryption requires a separate key for each pair of individuals who wish to have confidential communication, resulting in an exponential increase in the number of users as the number of users increase, creating an intractable distribution and storage problems. Public key infrastructure keys increase arithmetically, making it more practical from a scalability point of view.
justification.C: Public key cryptography typically requires more maintenance and is more costly than a symmetric key approach in small scale implementations.
justification.D: Secret key encryption requires shorter key lengths to achieve equivalent strength.

question: The implementation of an effective change management process is an example of a:

justification.A: A corrective control is designed to correct errors, omissions and unauthorized uses and intrusions once they are detected.
justification.B: Deterrent controls are intended to discourage individuals from intentionally violating information security policy or procedures. Change management is intended to reduce the introduction of vulnerability by unauthorized changes.
justification.C: An effective change management process can prevent (and detect) unauthorized changes. It requires formal approval, documentation and testing of all changes by a supervisory process.
justification.D: Compensating controls are meant to mitigate impact when existing controls fail. Change management is the primary control for preventing or detecting unauthorized changes. It is not compensating for another control that has that function.

question: Requirements for an information security program should be based PRIMARILY on which of the following choices?

justification.A: Policies are one of the resources used to develop the strategy, which is based on specific objectives that meet the requirements.
justification.B: The desired outcomes for the security program will be high-level achievements related to acceptable risk across the enterprise and will determine the requirements that must be met to achieve those outcomes.
justification.C: Objectives are the steps required to achieve the desired outcomes.
justification.D: The security strategy is the road map to achieve the objectives that result in the desired outcomes.

question: An information security manager has received complaints from senior management about the level of security delivered by a third-party service provider. The service provider is a long-standing vendor providing services based on a service agreement that has been renewed regularly without much change over the last four years. Which of the following actions is the FIRST one the information security manager should take in this situation?

options.A: Ensure that security requirements in the service agreement meet current business requirements.
options.B: Review security metrics to determine whether the vendor is meeting the terms of the service agreement.
options.C: Conduct a formal assessment of the vendor's capability to deliver security services.
options.D: Automate the incident reporting process to ensure timely reporting and monitoring.

justification.A: Because the service agreement has not been significantly revised in four years, it is entirely likely that the vendor is delivering exactly what was purchased and that the disappointment shown by senior management is the result of the agreement not reflecting current business requirements.
justification.B: Knowing whether the vendor is meeting the terms of the agreement is actionable only after the information security manager is certain that the terms of the agreement align with the business requirements of the company.
justification.C: If the vendor has committed to a level of security services that metrics indicate are consistently not being met, it may be worthwhile to conduct a formal assessment of the vendor's capabilities to determine whether a new vendor is needed. However, knowing how what was contracted aligns with business requirements needs to be the first step.
justification.D: Automation of the incident reporting process to ensure timely reporting and monitoring is only a reporting mechanism and does not resolve the issues faced.

question: How should an information security manager proceed when selecting a public cloud vendor to provide outsourced infrastructure and software?

options.A: Insist on strict service level agreements to guarantee application availability.
options.B: Verify that the vendor's security posture meets the enterprise's requirements.
options.C: Update the enterprise's security policies to reflect the vendor's agreement.
options.D: Consult a third party to provide an audit report to assess the vendor's security program.

justification.A: Agreements that address availability do not address other aspects of the enterprise's security policy.
justification.B: When considering a cloud implementation, an information security manager must verify that a chosen vendor will meet the enterprise's security requirements.
justification.C: An enterprise defines its security policies with its business risk in mind. Changing internal policy to reflect what a vendor can deliver may not be sufficient and could raise risk to the enterprise making it an inappropriate approach.
justification.D: Third-party audit reports are snapshots that tell what was true at a particular time and address only those items that were within the audit scope. Each enterprise has its own security policy considerations, and verification with the vendor should be accomplished with the enterprise's specific considerations and requirements in mind.

question: Which of the following approaches is the BEST for designing role-based access controls?

options.A: Create a matrix of work functions.

justification.A: A matrix that documents the functions associated with particular kinds of work, typically referred to as a segregation of duties matrix, shows which roles are required or need various permissions.
justification.B: Persistent data labels apply to mandatory access control environments where permissions are brokered by the classification levels of objects themselves. They do not factor into role-based access controls.
justification.C: Multifactor authentication deals with how users authenticate their identities, which helps to ensure that people are who they claim to be. It does not determine the permissions that they are assigned, particularly in a role-based access control model, where permissions are assigned to roles rather than individual users.
justification.D: Using automated logon scripts is practical in some environments, but assigning permissions to individual accounts is contrary to the intent of role-based access controls.

question: Which of the following change management process steps can be bypassed to implement an emergency change?

justification.A: Emergency changes require documentation, although it may occur after implementation.
justification.B: Emergency changes require formal authorization, although it may occur after implementation.
justification.C: When a change is being made on an emergency basis, it generally is implemented outside the normal schedule. However, it should not bypass other aspects of the change management process.
justification.D: Emergency changes require testing.

question: Which of the following criteria is the MOST essential for operational metrics?

options.D: The cost of obtaining the metrics

justification.A: Timeliness of reporting is important, but secondary to relevance.
justification.B: Unless the metric is relevant to the recipient and the recipient understands what the metric means and what action to take, if any, all other criteria are of little importance.
justification.C: A high degree of accuracy is not essential as long as the metric is reliable and indications are within an acceptable range.
justification.D: Cost is always a consideration, but secondary to the others.

question: Which of the following choices is the BEST indication that the information security manager is achieving the objective of value delivery?

justification.A: Value delivery means that good rates of return and a high utilization of resources are achieved.
justification.B: The budget level is not an indication of value delivery.
justification.C: The lowest cost vendors may not present the best value.
justification.D: Staff-associated overhead costs by themselves are not an indicator of value delivery.

question: What is the MOST important reason that an information security manager must have an understanding of information technology?

options.A: To ensure the proper configuration of the devices that store and process information
options.B: To understand the risk of technology and its contribution to security objectives
options.C: To assist and advise on the acquisition and deployment of information technology
options.D: To improve communication between information security and business functions

justification.A: The configuration of the devices is not the primary responsibility of the information security manager. The security manager will work through technical staff to ensure that configurations are appropriate.
justification.B: Knowledge of information technology helps the information security manager understand how changes in the technical environment affect the security posture and its contribution to control objectives.
justification.C: Advising on acquisition and deployment regarding security issues is a secondary function of the information security manager.
justification.D: Information security decisions can be made most effectively when they are understood by people in business functions, but this is secondary to understanding the relationship between technology and information security.

question: Which of the following conditions is MOST likely to require that a corporate standard be modified?

options.A: The standard does not conform to procedures.
options.B: IT staff does not understand the standard.
options.C: The standard is inconsistent with guidelines.
options.D: Control objectives are not being met.

justification.A: If a procedure does not meet the standard, the procedure must be changed, not the standard.
justification.B: IT staff not understanding the standard may require clarification and/or training.
justification.C: Inconsistencies with the guidelines require that the guidelines be changed to conform to the standard.
justification.D: If conformance with the standard does not achieve control objectives, the standard requires modification.

question: The protection of sensitive data stored at a third-party location requires:

options.A: assurances that the third party will comply with the requirements of the contract.
options.B: commitments to completion of periodic independent security audits.
options.C: security awareness training and background checks of all third-party employees.
options.D: periodic review of third-party contracts and policies to ensure compliance.

justification.A: When storing data with a third party, the ownership and responsibility for the adequate protection of the data remains with the outsourcing enterprise.
