The outsourcing enterprise should have measures in place to provide assurance of compliance with the terms of the contract, which should be written on the basis of the organizational risk appetite.
justification.B: Independent security audits are one assurance mechanism that an enterprise may use to verify compliance with contractual requirements, but whether they are appropriate is situational and based on the organizational risk appetite.
justification.C: Awareness training and background checks are assurance mechanisms but may or may not be appropriate or important in all cases.
justification.D: Review of contracts and policies is important, but it does not assure compliance.

question: A new business application requires deviation from the standard configuration of the operating system (OS). Which of the following steps should the security manager take FIRST?

options.A: Contact the vendor to modify the application.
options.B: Assess risk and identify compensating controls.
options.C: Approve an exception to the policy to meet business needs.
options.D: Review and update the OS baseline configuration.

justification.A: The security manager would contact the vendor to modify the application only after assessing the risk and identifying compensating controls.
justification.B: Before approving any exception, the security manager should first check for compensating controls and assess the possible risk due to deviation.
justification.C: The security manager may make a case for deviation from the policy, but this would be based on a risk assessment and compensating controls. The deviation itself would be approved in accordance with a defined process.
justification.D: Updating the baseline configuration is not associated with requests for deviations.

question: Which of the following training mechanisms is the MOST effective means of promoting an organizational security culture?

options.A: Choose a subset of influential people to promote the benefits of the security program.
options.B: Hold structured training in small groups on an annual basis.
options.C: Require each employee to complete a self-paced training module once per year.
options.D: Deliver training to all employees across the enterprise via streaming video.

justification.A: Certain people are either individually inclined or required by their positions to have greater interest in promoting security than others. By selecting these people and offering them broad, diverse opportunities for security education, they are able to act as ambassadors to their respective teams and departments, imparting a gradual and significant change in an organizational culture toward better security.
justification.B: Structured training rarely aligns with the interests of individual employees when chosen at random to fill a small group setting.
justification.C: Computer-based training is a common approach to annual information awareness, but there is limited evidence that employees retain the information or adopt it into their regular activities.
justification.D: Streaming-video webinars are among the least effective means of presenting information, requiring very little interaction from end users.

question: Which of the following challenges associated with information security documentation is MOST likely to affect a large, established enterprise?

options.A: Standards change more slowly than the environment.
options.B: Policies change faster than they can be distributed.
options.C: Procedures are ignored to meet operational requirements.
options.D: Policies remain unchanged for long periods of time.

justification.A: Large, established enterprises tend to have numerous layers of review and approval associated with changes to standards. These review mechanisms are likely to be outpaced by changes in technology and the risk environment.
justification.B: Policies are meant to reflect strategic goals and objectives. In small or immature enterprises, the policy model may be poorly implemented, resulting in rapid changes to policies that are treated more like standards, but this situation is unlikely to arise in a large, established enterprise.
justification.C: Large, established enterprises typically have formal training programs and internal controls that keep activities substantially in line with published procedures.
justification.D: Although policies should be subject to periodic review and not be regarded as static, properly written policies should require significant changes only when there are substantial changes in strategic goals and objectives. It is reasonable that a large, established enterprise would experience policy changes only rarely.

question: In a financial institution, under which of the following circumstances will policies MOST likely need modification?

options.A: Current access controls have been insufficient to prevent a series of serious network breaches.
options.B: The information security manager has determined that compliance with configuration standards is inadequate.
options.C: The results of an audit have identified a going concern issue with the enterprise.
options.D: Management has mandated compliance with a newly enacted set of information security requirements.

justification.A: Necessary modifications to access controls are most likely going to be reflected in standards, not policy.
justification.B: Compliance with existing standards is not likely to require a policy change; better enforcement may be needed.
justification.C: If the viability of the enterprise is in doubt (going concern), it is not likely that a change in policy will solve the problem.
justification.D: A new set of regulations requiring significant changes to the information security program most likely will be reflected in modifications of policy.

question: Which of the following tools should a newly hired information security manager review to gain an understanding of how effectively the current set of information security projects are managed?

justification.A: A project database may contain information for one specific project and updates to various parameters pertaining to the current status of that single project.
justification.B: A project portfolio database is the basis for project portfolio management. It includes project data such as owner, schedules, objectives, project type, status and cost. Project portfolio management requires specific project portfolio reports.
justification.C: Policy documents on project management set direction for the design, development, implementation and monitoring of the project.
justification.D: A program management office is the team that oversees the delivery of the project portfolio. Review of the office may provide meaningful insights into the skill set and organizational structure but not on how effectively the current set of information security projects are managed.

question: What is the MAIN objective for developing an information security program?

options.A: To create the information security policy

justification.A: The policy should not be written for its own sake. To be effective, the policy must address the threat and risk landscape that is usually the basis for strategy development.
justification.B: The degree of uptime required will be defined as a part of strategy development balanced against costs.
justification.C: Not all controls need to be strong, and the degree of control must be determined by cost-effectiveness, impact on productivity and other factors.
justification.D: The information security strategy provides a development road map to which the program is built.

question: An information security manager has implemented an automated process to compare physical access using swipe cards operated by the physical security department with logical access in the single sign-on (SSO) system. What is the MOST likely use for this information?

justification.A: Discrepancies between physical and logical access can occur for a variety of reasons, but all are indications that something is wrong and risk is elevated. Discrepancies could indicate piggybacking, shared passwords or attempts at unauthorized access, and therefore, this monitoring can serve as a key risk indicator (KRI).
justification.B: Potential piggybacking can be flagged if more individuals log in from within the network than physically enter the facility; however, this is just one KRI.
justification.C: Although this information could indicate that the physical access control is not functioning properly, the responsibility for oversight of the physical security department is not usually a function of the information security manager.
justification.D: Comparing physical access and logical access is not an effective way to monitor the single sign-on (SSO) system, and there are other methods more specific and useful for this purpose.

question: Which of the following will BEST protect an enterprise from insider security attacks?

justification.A: Static Internet Protocol addressing does little to prevent an insider attack.
justification.B: Internal address translation using non-routable addresses is useful against external attacks but not against insider attacks.
justification.C: Because past performance is a strong predictor of future performance, background checks of prospective employees best prevent attacks from originating within an enterprise.
justification.D: Employees who certify that they have read security policies are desirable; but this does not guarantee that the employees behave honestly.

question: What is the PRIMARY benefit of performing an information asset classification?

options.A: It links security requirements to business objectives.
options.B: It identifies controls commensurate with impact.

justification.A: Asset classification indirectly links security to business objectives on the basis of business value of assets.
justification.B: Classification levels are based on the business value (or potential impact) of assets and the stronger controls needed for higher classification.
justification.C: Classification does not define access rights.
justification.D: Classification does not establish ownership.

question: The relationship between policies and corporate standards can BEST be described by which of the following associations?

options.A: Standards and policies have only an indirect relationship.
options.B: Standards provide a detailed description of the meaning of a policy.
options.C: Standards provide direction on achieving compliance with policy intent.
options.D: Standards can exist without a relationship to any particular policy.

justification.A: In most cases, there is a direct relationship between policy and corporate standards.
justification.B: Corporate standards generally do not provide details on the meaning of policy, rather on the acceptable limits needed to comply with policy intent.
justification.C: Corporate standards set the allowable limits and boundaries for people, processes and technology as an expression of policy intent and, therefore, provide direction on policy compliance.
justification.D: It would be a poor practice to have corporate standards not directly expressing the intent of a particular policy. To the extent that they exist, they should rely on an implicit policy.

question: A person working at a bank receives a call on a voice-over Internet protocol line from a person claiming to be an employee of the bank at another branch office. He is requesting customer information. The FIRST action to take when receiving this type of call is to:

options.A: obtain the email address of the caller and have the recipient transmit the information using message encryption.
options.B: advise the employee who received the call to hang up and then return the call to the other branch using the number in the office phone directory.
options.C: pose business-related questions to the caller, and if a proper reply is received, the recipient may forward the information to the caller.
options.D: ask the person to call back later and notify regulatory officers of a possible fraud attempt.

justification.A: Sensitive information should not be sent to a third party that has not been validated even if encryption is used, because the enterprise cannot guarantee that the recipient will be unable to decipher information in a time period during which the information can still be used.
justification.B: If the call recipient suspects any chance of social engineering over the phone, the callback option is quite effective. The best approach to confirm the caller's identity is to call back using the legitimate phone number listed in the office phone directory. The recipient should not use a phone number or email address provided by the caller. Once the legitimacy of the call has been reasonably verified, the information may be transmitted using message encryption. Even after voice verification, it is essential that encryption be used because voice verification might be subject to additional attacks (e.g., man-in-the-middle).
justification.C: Even when there is a strong suspicion of fraud, the recipient should not indicate this to the caller over the phone. Instead, the recipient should hang up and call back using the phone number from the office phone directory.
justification.D: The person attempting social engineering will attempt to pass business (or non-business) related questions to the caller. If proper answers are obtained, the recipient will continue the conversation. A caller who feels uneasy will have the control to end the conversation. Because this technique gives the attacker control of the conversation, it is not the best answer.

question: Which of the following attacks is BEST mitigated by using strong passwords?

justification.A: Man-in-the-middle attacks intercept network traffic and must be protected by encryption.
justification.B: Strong passwords mitigate brute force attacks.
justification.C: Buffer overflow attacks may not be protected by passwords.
justification.D: Root kits hook into the operating system's kernel and, therefore, operate underneath any authentication mechanism.

question: Which of the following reasons is MOST likely why an enterprise has decided to outsource intrusion detection services?

options.A: As a response to audit recommendations
options.B: Due to the complexity of interpreting attacks
options.C: As a result of a cost-benefit analysis
options.D: Due to lack of competent staff

justification.A: Audit recommendations may lead to a cost-benefit analysis, but generally do not direct a particular approach to solving an identified problem.
justification.B: Technology for intrusion detection that reduces complexity to manage the levels is available but may not be cost-effective.
justification.C: A cost-benefit analysis addresses the trade-offs between in-house and outsourced services. If outsourcing is chosen, it is generally chosen on the basis of cost-effectiveness.
justification.D: Hiring staff with the proper skill set for intrusion detection is generally possible but may not be cost-effective.

question: Phishing is BEST mitigated by which of the following?

justification.A: Security monitoring software is generally incapable of detecting a phishing attack.
justification.B: Encryption would not mitigate a phishing attack.
justification.C: Two-factor authentication would not mitigate this threat.
justification.D: Phishing is a type of email attack that attempts to convince a user that the originator is genuine, but with the intention of obtaining information for use in social engineering. It can best be mitigated by appropriate user awareness.

question: What is the initial step that an information security manager would take during the requirements gathering phase of an IT project to avoid project failure?

options.A: Develop a comprehensive methodology that defines and documents project needs.
options.B: Build security requirements into the design of the system with consideration of enterprise security needs.
options.C: Ensure that the business problem is clearly understood before working on the solution.
options.D: Create a project plan based on the principles of agile development methodology.

justification.A: Developing a methodology is a step separate from defining requirements.
justification.B: The question relates to requirements-gathering phase of the project, not the design phase. Therefore, it would be too early to start building the requirement into the design.
justification.C: The key to successful requirements gathering is to focus initially on the business problem before trying to develop a solution. Otherwise, the solution may address the wrong problem.
justification.D: An agile development methodology first requires the determination of business requirements.

question: What is the PRIMARY benefit of a security awareness training program?

options.A: To reduce the likelihood of an information security event
options.B: To encourage compliance with information security policy
options.C: To comply with the local and industry-specific regulation and legislation
options.D: To provide employees with expectations for information security

justification.A: Employees should know how information security relates to their job roles and how to perform work tasks appropriately to protect the enterprise and its assets.
justification.B: Although compliance with the information security policy is important, security awareness training goes beyond cultural and behavioral elements of information security.
justification.C: Industry-specific regulation and legislation are not the primary drivers of security awareness training programs.
justification.D: Employee expectations do not necessarily ensure understanding of information security or influence cultural or behavioral attitudes directly.

question: Who has the inherent authority to grant an exception to information security policy?

justification.A: The business process owner is typically required to enforce the policy and would not normally have the authority to grant an exception.
justification.B: The departmental manager cannot approve an exception to policy because the role is not responsible for the policy delivering its promised results.
justification.C: The person or body empowered to approve a policy is empowered to grant exceptions to it because in approving it, the individual assumed responsibility for the results that it promises to deliver.
justification.D: The information security manager cannot approve an exception to policy because the role is not responsible for the policy delivering its promised results.

question: What human resources (HR) activity is MOST crucial in managing mobile devices supplied by the enterprise? HR provides:

justification.A: When the human resources (HR) department provides staff termination notices, security management can perform deprovisioning of mobile devices.
justification.B: Background checks generally do not help the management of mobile devices.
justification.C: Reporting structures generally do not affect the management of mobile devices.
justification.D: HR could support information security awareness programs. However, from the management perspective, device deprovisioning upon staff termination will be more important.

question: Which of the following types of information would the information security manager expect to have the LOWEST level of security protection in a publicly traded, multinational enterprise?

justification.A: The strategic business plan is private information and should only be accessed by authorized entities.
justification.B: Upcoming financial results are private information and should only be accessed by authorized entities.
justification.C: Customer personal information is private information and should only be accessed by authorized entities.
justification.D: Previous financial results are public; all the other choices are private information and should only be accessed by authorized entities.

question: Which of the following is the PRIMARY prerequisite to implementing data classification within an enterprise?

justification.A: Defining job roles is not relevant.
justification.B: Performing a risk assessment is important but will require the participation of data owners (who must first be identified).
justification.C: Identifying the data owners is the first step and is essential to implementing data classification.
justification.D: Establishing data retention policies may occur at any time.

question: When implementing a cloud computing solution that will provide software as a service (SaaS) to the enterprise, what is the GREATEST concern for the information security manager?

options.A: The lack of clear regulations regarding the storage of data with a third party
options.B: The training of the users to access the new technology properly
options.C: The risk of network failure and the resulting loss of application availability
options.D: The possibility of disclosure of sensitive data in transit or storage

justification.A: Disclosure of sensitive data is a primary concern of the information security manager.
justification.B: Many jurisdictions have regulations regarding data privacy. The concern of the information security manager is compliance with those regulations, not the lack of regulations.
justification.C: The training of how to use software as a service (SaaS) is no different from the need for training required for more traditional solutions. In most cases, the use of SaaS is fairly simple and requires minimal technology but is not within the scope of the information security manager's responsibility in any case.
justification.D: Loss of application availability as a result of network failure is an inherent risk associated with SaaS and must be taken into account by the enterprise as part of the decision to move to cloud computing, but this is a business decision rather than a principal concern of the information security manager.

question: An advantage of using a cloud computing solution over a locally hosted solution is:

options.A: the ability to obtain storage and bandwidth on demand.
options.B: reduced requirements for training of users and managers.
options.C: increased security as a result of encrypting data in transit.
options.D: the opportunity to control changes to applications and data.

justification.A: One key advantage of cloud computing is the ability to rapidly adjust storage and network bandwidth needs as required. This is generally not possible in locally hosted environments.
justification.B: The amount of training required for users and managers is not substantially different between a cloud and a local solution.
justification.C: Sensitive data can be encrypted in transit regardless of whether it is locally hosted or hosted on a cloud provider.
justification.D: Access controls may be established in both local and cloud solutions.

question: To establish the contractual relationship between entities using public key infrastructure, the certificate authority must provide which of the following?

justification.A: The registration authority is responsible for authentication of users prior to the issuance of a certificate.
justification.B: A digital certificate is the electronic credentials of individual entities but does not provide the contractual relationship of users and the certificate authority.
justification.C: Nonrepudiation is an inherent capability of a public key infrastructure by the virtue of the signing capability.
justification.D: The certification practice statement provides the contractual requirements between the relying parties and the certificate authority.

question: Which of the following control practices represents the FIRST layer of the defense-in-depth strategy?

justification.A: Data privacy is part of the second layer, which is containment.
justification.B: Authentication is part of prevention, which is the first layer of defense in depth.
justification.C: Incident response is part of the fourth layer of defense, which is reaction.
justification.D: A backup policy is part of the last layer of defense, which is recovery/restoration.

question: A project manager is developing a developer portal and requests that the security manager assign a public Internet Protocol address so that it can be accessed by in-house staff and by external consultants outside the enterprise's local area network. What should the security manager do FIRST?

options.A: Understand the business requirements of the developer portal.
options.B: Perform a vulnerability assessment of the developer portal.
options.D: Obtain a signed nondisclosure agreement from the external consultants before allowing external access to the server.

justification.A: The information security manager cannot make an informed decision about the request without first understanding the business requirements of the developer portal.
justification.B: Performing a vulnerability assessment of developer portal is prudent but it should follow understanding the requirements.
justification.C: Installing an intrusion detection system may be useful but not as essential as understanding the requirements.
justification.D: Obtaining a signed nondisclosure agreement is a prudent practice but is secondary to understanding requirements.

question: The MOST likely reason to segment a network by trust domains is to:

justification.A: Segmentation by trust domain limits the potential consequences of a successful compromise by constraining the scope of impact.
justification.B: Segmentation by trust domain does not substantially change vulnerability.
justification.C: Automated network scanning can treat a network as logically segmented without reliance on trust domains.
justification.D: Segmentation is not implemented primarily to facilitate data classification.

question: A mission-critical system has been identified as having an administrative system account with attributes that prevent locking and change of privileges and name. Which would be the BEST approach to prevent a successful brute force attack of the account?

options.A: Prevent the system from being accessed remotely.
options.D: Track usage of the account by audit trails.

justification.A: Preventing the system from being accessed remotely is not always an option in mission-critical systems and still leaves local access risk.
justification.B: Creating a strong random password reduces the risk of a successful brute force attack by exponentially increasing the time required.
justification.C: Vendor patches are not always available.
justification.D: Tracking usage is a detective control and will not prevent an attack.

question: Business management is finalizing the contents of a segregation of duties matrix to be loaded in a purchase order system. Which of the following should the information security manager recommend in order to BEST improve the effectiveness of the matrix?

options.A: Ensure approvers are aligned with the organizational chart
options.B: Trace approvers' paths to eliminate routing deadlocks
options.C: Set triggers to go off in the event of exceptions
options.D: Identify conflicts in the approvers' authority limits

justification.A: The approver's structure in a purchase order system may not necessarily be in sync with the organizational structure. Depending on business requirements, modified hierarchy is acceptable purely in terms of approving certain transactions.
justification.B: It is rare that the structure of an approver's routing path will end up with deadlocks. If a highly complicated structure is developed, something similar to deadlock may occur (e.g., it takes very long until request is approved). Even so, it is unlikely that routing effectiveness becomes a primary driver for quality improvement.
justification.C: Setting triggers to go off in the event of exceptions is a technical feature to be implemented inside the database. It is not relevant advice to be given to business management.
justification.D: In order to make the segregation of duties matrix complete, it is best to ensure that no conflicts exist in approvers' authorities. If there are any, it will introduce a flaw in the control, resulting in the successful execution of unauthorized transactions.

question: Active information security awareness programs PRIMARILY influence:

justification.A: The level of risk that an enterprise deems acceptable is a business decision. Controls, including active security awareness programs, are implemented to reduce risk to acceptable levels and do not influence what level of risk is acceptable.
justification.B: An information security awareness program is an administrative control that reduces vulnerability, thereby yielding lower residual risk.
justification.C: Security awareness may be a control objective, depending on the information security strategy of the enterprise, but such a program does not primarily influence the objectives of other controls.
justification.D: Security awareness does not primarily influence business objectives.

question: A company recently developed a breakthrough technology. Because this technology could give this company a significant competitive edge, which of the following would FIRST govern how this information is to be protected?

justification.A: Without a mandated ranking of degree of protection, it is difficult to determine what access controls should be in place.
justification.B: Data classification policies define the level of protection to be provided for each category of data based on business value.
justification.C: Without a mandated ranking of degree of protection, it is difficult to determine what levels of encryption should be in place.
justification.D: An acceptable use policy is oriented more toward the end user and, therefore, would not specifically address what controls should be in place to adequately protect information.

question: When considering outsourcing technical or business processes, one of the MAIN concerns of the information security manager is whether the third-party service provider will:

options.A: deliver a level of quality acceptable to the enterprise's established customer base.
options.B: agree to service level agreements with penalties sufficient to offset potential losses.
options.C: provide technical services at a lower cost than would be possible on an in-house basis.
options.D: meet the enterprise's security requirements on an ongoing and verifiable basis.

justification.A: Quality assurance is an area of concern when dealing with third-party service providers, but it is not a primary focus of the information security manager.
justification.B: Penalties written into service level agreements are a form of risk transfer (sharing) that may be appropriate for an enterprise's business objectives, but the sufficiency of such arrangements are not a primary focus of the information security manager.
justification.C: Reducing or controlling cost is typically one of the main reasons that enterprises choose to enter into third-party service agreements, but whether such agreements deliver their expected cost savings is not a primary focus of the information security manager.
justification.D: When an enterprise enters into an outsourcing agreement with a third-party service provider, the information security manager becomes responsible for ensuring that the provider adheres to the same security requirements as apply to the enterprise itself and that any variances are documented and presented to senior management for an appropriate risk response. The challenge of being able to assess a provider's security behaviors on an ongoing and verifiable basis is one of the main concerns of the information security manager in any outsourcing arrangement.

question: IT management has standardized the Internet browser used within the enterprise. This practice is MOST effective in meeting which of the following objectives?

options.A: Prevent attacks designed to exploit known vulnerabilities.
options.B: Ensure the subscription count is aligned with contract.
options.C: Invalidate illegal browser script program development.
options.D: Guarantee compatibility with internal web-based applications.

justification.A: Standardization of browsers within enterprises typically results in delays to upgrades and patching, making it more likely that the standardized browser will be susceptible to exploitation of known vulnerabilities.
justification.B: Controlling the version of the Internet browser used may not support the reconciliation between the subscription count and contract license number.
justification.C: Browser script development is generally not constrained by browser standardization. Information security managers seeking to prevent script execution would typically do so by standardizing configurations rather than versions.
justification.D: Internal web applications typically depend on particular versions of a web browser. Many enterprises choose to retain versions of their browsers beyond periods of support in order to maintain compatibility with their deployed applications.

question: What is the BEST method for mitigating against network denial-of-service (DoS) attacks?

options.A: Ensure all servers are up to date on operating system patches.
options.B: Employ packet filtering to drop suspect packets.
options.C: Implement network address translation to make internal addresses non-routable.
options.D: Implement load balancing for Internet-facing devices.

justification.A: In general, patching servers will not affect network traffic.
justification.B: Packet filtering techniques are the only ones which reduce network congestion caused by a network denial-of-service (DoS) attack.
justification.C: Implementing network address translation would not be effective in mitigating most network DoS attacks.
justification.D: Load balancing would not be as effective in mitigating most network DoS attacks.

question: Which of the following would be the BEST metric for an information security manager to provide to support a request to fund new controls?

justification.A: Security incidents occur because either a control failed or there was no control in place. Trends are a metric providing their own points of reference.
justification.B: Failures of compliance with existing controls are not likely to be solved by additional controls. Also, an audit finding absent any prior findings of compliance or other reference point is a measure, not a metric.
justification.C: Without knowing exposure, threat and potential impact, risk cannot be determined and will be poor support for new controls. Also, results of a vulnerability scan constitute a measure, not a metric.
justification.D: Port scans are common and generally will not support funding of new controls.

question: The MOST timely and effective approach to detecting nontechnical security violations in an enterprise is:

options.A: the development of enterprise-wide communication channels.
options.B: periodic third-party auditing of incident reporting logs.
options.C: an automated policy compliance monitoring system.
options.D: deployment of suggestion boxes throughout the enterprise.

justification.A: Timely reporting of all security-related activities provides the information needed to monitor and respond to information security governance issues. Effective communication channels also are important for disseminating security-related information to the enterprise.
justification.B: Audits are one form of periodic reporting, but they are too infrequent for effective day-to-day information security management.
justification.C: Automated policy compliance monitoring is useful for reporting IT-related processes but, by itself, is insufficient for nontechnical security violations.
justification.D: Even if personnel could be persuaded to leave notes on policy violations in suggestion boxes, it would not be effective and is unlikely to be timely unless suggestions are collected daily.

question: Which program element should be implemented FIRST in asset classification and control?

justification.A: Risk assessment is performed to identify and quantify threats to information assets that are selected by the first step, valuation.
justification.B: Classification is a step following valuation.
justification.C: Valuation is performed first to identify and understand the value of assets needing protection.
justification.D: Risk mitigation is a step following valuation based on the valuation.

question: Why is asset classification important to a successful information security program?

options.A: It determines the priority and extent of risk mitigation efforts.
options.B: It determines the amount of insurance needed in case of loss.
options.C: It determines the appropriate level of protection to the asset.
options.D: It determines how protection levels compare to peer enterprises.

justification.A: Classification does not determine the priority and extent of the risk mitigation efforts; prioritization of risk mitigation efforts is generally based on risk analysis or a business impact analysis.
justification.B: Classification does not establish the amount of insurance needed; insurance is often not a viable option.
justification.C: Classification is based on the value of the asset to the enterprise and helps establish the protection level in proportion to the value of the asset.
justification.D: Classification schemes differ from enterprise to enterprise and are often not suitable for benchmarking.

question: What is a reasonable approach to determine control effectiveness?

options.A: Determine whether the control is preventive, detective or corrective.
options.B: Review the control's capability of providing notification of failure.
options.C: Confirm the control's ability to meet intended objectives.
options.D: Assess and quantify the control's reliability.

justification.A: The type of control is not relevant.
justification.B: Notification of failure is not determinative of control effectiveness.
justification.C: Control effectiveness requires a process to verify that the control process works as intended. Examples such as dual-control or dual-entry bookkeeping provide verification and assurance that the process operated as intended.
justification.D: Reliability is not an indication of control strength; weak controls can be highly reliable, even if they are ineffective controls.

question: The PRIMARY reason for initiating a policy exception process is when:

options.A: operations are too busy to comply.
options.B: the risk is justified by the benefit.
options.C: policy compliance would be difficult to enforce.

justification.A: Being busy is not a justification for policy exceptions.
justification.B: Exceptions to policy are warranted in circumstances where compliance may be difficult or impossible and the risk of noncompliance is outweighed by the benefits.
justification.C: The fact that compliance cannot be enforced is not a justification for policy exceptions.
justification.D: User inconvenience is not a reason to automatically grant exception to a policy.

question: Which of the following would be the MOST relevant factor when defining the information classification policy?

justification.A: The quantity of information is not a factor in defining the information classification policy.
justification.B: The availability of IT infrastructure would not be a significant factor in determining the policy.
justification.C: Benchmarking would not be a factor in defining the classification policy.
justification.D: When defining the information classification policy, the requirements of the data owners need to be identified.

question: Abnormal server communication from inside the enterprise to external parties may be monitored to:

options.A: record the trace of advanced persistent threats.
options.B: evaluate the process resiliency of server operations.
options.C: verify the effectiveness of an intrusion detection system.
options.D: support a nonrepudiation framework in e-commerce.

justification.A: The most important feature of target attacks as seen in advanced persistent threats is that malware secretly sends information back to a command and control server. Therefore, monitoring of outbound server communications that do not follow predefined routes will be the best control to detect such security events.
justification.B: Server communications are usually not monitored to evaluate the resiliency of server operations.
justification.C: The effectiveness of an intrusion detection system may not be verified by monitoring outbound server communications.
justification.D: Nonrepudiation may be supported by technology, such as a digital signature. Server communication itself does not support the effectiveness of an e-commerce framework.

question: Which of the following authentication methods prevents authentication replay?

justification.A: Capturing the authentication handshake and replaying it through the network will not work. Using hashes by itself will not prevent a replay.
justification.B: A challenge/response mechanism prevents replay attacks by sending a different random challenge in each authentication event. The response is linked to that challenge.
justification.C: A wired equivalent privacy key will not prevent sniffing, but it will take the attacker longer to break the WEP key if they do not already have it. Therefore, it will not be able to prevent recording and replaying an authentication handshake.
justification.D: Hypertext Transfer Protocol basic authentication is cleartext and has no mechanisms to prevent replay.

question: What is the PRIMARY purpose of segregation of duties?

justification.A: Segregation of duties (SoD) is unrelated to monitoring.
justification.B: As a secondary benefit, some reduction in supervision may be possible.
justification.C: SoD is primarily used to prevent fraudulent activities.
justification.D: If SoD is a policy requirement, then a secondary benefit is enhanced compliance. However, the policy exists to reduce fraud.

question: What is the BEST means to standardize security configurations in similar devices?

justification.A: Policies set high-level direction, not technical details.
justification.B: Procedures are used to provide instructions on accomplishing specific tasks.
justification.C: Technical guides provide support but not necessarily the requirements.
justification.D: Baselines describe the minimum configuration requirements across similar devices, activities or resources.

question: Which of the following provides the BEST defense against the introduction of malware in end-user computers via the Internet browser?

options.A: Input validation checks on structured query language injection
options.B: Restricting access to social media sites

justification.A: Validation of checks on structured query language injection does not apply to this scenario.
justification.B: Restricting access to social media sites may be helpful but is not the primary source of malware.
justification.C: Deleting temporary files is not applicable to this scenario.
justification.D: Restricting execution of mobile code is the most effective way to avoid introduction of malware into the end user's computers.

question: A social media application system has a process to scan posted comments in search of inappropriate disclosures. Which of the following choices would circumvent this control?

justification.A: Depending on the font style, text messages may become illegible; however, character codes stay the same behind the scenes. Therefore, scanning may not be affected by font settings.
justification.B: Even when a message is posted using a stolen identity, scanning will be able to catch an inappropriate posting by checking text against a predefined vocabulary table.
justification.C: Absence of the identity of the user who posted an inappropriate message may not be a major issue in conducting the scanning of posted information.
justification.D: Intentional misspellings are hard to detect by fixed rules or keyword search because it is difficult for the system to consider the possible misspellings. The computer may ignore misspelled items. Because humans can understand the context, it is rather easy for humans to sense the true intention hidden behind the misspelling.

question: Which of the following factors will MOST affect the extent to which controls should be layered?

options.A: The extent to which controls are procedural
options.B: The extent to which controls are subject to the same threat
options.C: The total cost of ownership for existing controls
options.D: The extent to which controls fail in a closed condition

justification.A: Whether controls are procedural or technical will not affect layering requirements.
justification.B: To manage the aggregate risk of total risk, common failure modes in existing controls must be addressed by adding or modifying controls so that they fail under different conditions.
justification.C: The total cost of ownership is unlikely to be reduced by adding additional controls.
justification.D: Controls that fail in a closed condition pose a risk to availability, whereas controls that fail in an open condition may require additional control layers to prevent compromise.

question: Which of the following is a preventive measure?

justification.A: A warning banner is a deterrent control, which provides a warning that can deter potential compromise.
justification.B: Audit trails are an example of a detective control.
justification.C: Preventive controls inhibit attempts to violate security policies. An example of such a control is an access control.
justification.D: An alarm system is an example of a detective control.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important to keep in mind when assessing the value of information?

options.B: The cost of recreating the information

justification.A: The potential for financial loss is always a key factor when assessing the value of information.
justification.B: The cost of recreating the information may be a contributor but not the key factor.
justification.C: The cost of insurance coverage may be a contributor but not the key factor.
justification.D: Regulatory requirements may be a contributor but not the key factor.

question: The information classification scheme should:

options.A: consider possible impact of a security breach.
options.B: classify personal information in electronic form.
options.C: be performed by the information security manager.
options.D: be based on a risk assessment.

justification.A: Data classification is determined by the business value of the asset (i.e., the potential impact on the business of the loss, corruption or disclosure of information).
justification.B: Classification of personal information in electronic form is an incomplete answer because it addresses a subset of organizational data.
justification.C: Information classification is performed by the data owner based on accepted security criteria.
justification.D: The risk to a particular asset is not the basis for classification, rather the potential impact from compromise is the basis.

question: Which of the following is the BEST method to provide a new user with their initial password for email system access?

options.A: Provide a system-generated complex password by interoffice mail with 30 days expiration.
options.B: Provide a temporary password over the telephone set for immediate expiration.
options.C: Require no password but force the user to set their own in 10 days.
options.D: Set initial password equal to the user ID with expiration in 30 days.

justification.A: Documenting the password on paper is not the best method even if sent through interoffice mail—if the password is complex and difficult to memorize, the user will likely keep the printed password, and this creates a security concern.
justification.B: A temporary password that will need to be changed upon first logon is the best method because it is reset immediately and is replaced with the user's choice of password, which will make it easier for the user to remember. If it is given to the wrong person, the legitimate user will likely notify security if still unable to access the system; therefore, the security risk is low.
justification.C: Setting an account with no initial password is a security concern even if it is just for a few days.
justification.D: This provides the greatest security threat because user IDs are typically known by both users and security staff, thus compromising access for up to 30 days.

question: An operating system noncritical patch to enhance system security cannot be applied because a critical application is not compatible with the change. Which of the following is the BEST solution?

options.A: Rewrite the application to conform with the upgraded operating system.
options.B: Compensate for not installing the patch with mitigating controls.
options.C: Alter the patch to allow the application to run in a privileged state.
options.D: Run the application on a test platform; tune production to allow patch and application.

justification.A: Rewriting the application is not a viable option.
justification.B: Because the operating system (OS) patch will adversely impact a critical application, a mitigating control should be identified that will provide an equivalent level of security.
justification.C: Altering the OS patch to allow the application to run in a privileged state is likely to create new security weaknesses.
justification.D: Running a production application on a test platform is not an acceptable alternative because it will mean running a critical production application on a platform not subject to the same level of security controls.

question: What is the PRIMARY basis for the selection of controls and countermeasures?

justification.A: The focus must include procedural, operational and other risk—not just IT risk.
justification.B: The balance between cost and benefits should direct controls selection.
justification.C: Resource management is not directly related to controls.
justification.D: The implementation of controls is based on the impact and risk, not on the number of assets.

question: What is the PRIMARY purpose of performing an internal attack and penetration test?

options.A: Identify weaknesses in network and server security.
options.B: Identify ways to improve the incident response process.
options.C: Identify attack vectors on the network perimeter.
options.D: Identify the optimum response to internal hacker attacks.

justification.A: Internal attack and penetration tests are designed to identify weaknesses in network and server security.
justification.B: Internal attack and penetration tests do not focus on incident response.
justification.C: The network perimeter is about external attacks.
justification.D: Possible responses can be a secondary follow-up effort after the internal attack and penetration test.

question: Which of the following tasks should the information security manager do FIRST when business information has to be shared with external entities?

justification.A: Execution of a nondisclosure agreement may be needed after the classification of the data to be shared is determined.
justification.B: The information security manager should first determine whether sharing the information poses a risk for the enterprise based on the information classification.
justification.C: Whether a secure channel is needed is a function of the classification of data to be shared.
justification.D: Encryption requirements will be determined as a function of the classification of data to be shared.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important element of information asset classification?

justification.A: Residual risk is unrelated to asset classification.
justification.B: Segregation of duties is a control unrelated to asset classification.
justification.C: Classification levels must be based on the level of impact that would occur as a result of compromise.
justification.D: Need to know is a control indirectly related to asset classification.

question: Which of the following should be determined FIRST when establishing a business continuity program?

options.A: Cost to rebuild information processing facilities
options.B: Incremental daily cost of the unavailability of systems
options.C: Location and cost of offsite recovery facilities
options.D: Composition and mission of individual recovery teams

justification.A: The cost to rebuild information processing facilities would not be the first thing to determine.
justification.B: Prior to creating a detailed business continuity plan, it is important to determine the incremental daily cost of losing different systems. This will allow recovery time objectives to be determined.
justification.C: Location and cost of a recovery facility cannot be addressed until the potential losses are calculated, which will determine the type of recovery site that is needed—and this will affect cost.
justification.D: Individual recovery team requirements will occur after the requirements for business continuity are determined.

question: A company has a network of branch offices with local file/print and mail servers; each branch individually contracts a hot site. Which of the following would be the GREATEST weakness in recovery capability?

options.A: Exclusive use of the hot site is limited to six weeks.
options.B: The hot site may have to be shared with other customers.
options.C: The time of declaration determines site access priority.
options.D: The provider services all major companies in the area.

justification.A: Access to a hot site is not indefinite; the recovery plan should address a long-term outage.
justification.B: Sharing a hot site facility is common practice and sometimes necessary in the case of a major disaster, and it is not a significant weakness.
justification.C: First come, first served is a standard practice in hosted facilities and does not constitute a major weakness.
justification.D: In case of a disaster affecting a localized geographical area, the vendor's facility and capabilities could be insufficient for all its clients, which will be competing for the same resource. Preference will likely be given to the larger corporations, possibly delaying the recovery of a branch that will likely be smaller than other clients based locally.

question: Which of the following actions should be taken when an online trading company discovers a network attack in progress?

options.A: Shut off all network access points
options.B: Dump all event logs to removable media
options.D: Enable trace logging on all events

justification.A: Shutting off all network access points would create a denial of service that could result in loss of revenue.
justification.B: Dumping event logs, while useful, would not mitigate the immediate threat posed by the network attack.
justification.C: Isolating the affected network segment will mitigate the immediate threat while allowing unaffected portions of the business to continue processing.
justification.D: Enabling trace logging, while useful, would not mitigate the immediate threat posed by the network attack.

question: Which of the following choices should be assessed after the likelihood of a loss event has been determined?

justification.A: Disaster recovery is driven by risk, which is a combination of likelihood and consequences. Once likelihood has been determined, the next step is to determine the magnitude of impact.
justification.B: Risk tolerance is the acceptable deviation from acceptable risk. This is taken into account once risk has been quantified, which is dependent on determining the magnitude of impact.
justification.C: Replacement cost is needed only when replacement is required.
justification.D: Book value does not represent actual asset value and cannot be used to measure magnitude of impact.

question: What is the FIRST priority when responding to a major security incident?

justification.A: Documentation is important, but it should follow containment.
justification.B: Monitoring is important and should be ongoing but does not limit the impact of the incident.
justification.C: Restoration follows containment.
justification.D: The first priority in responding to a security incident is to contain it to limit the impact.

question: Although control effectiveness has recently been tested, a serious compromise occurred. What is the FIRST action the information security manager should take?

justification.A: Control objectives cannot be evaluated until the exact nature of the compromise is understood; therefore, it is not clear how to best provide a solution.
justification.B: Increasing the restrictiveness of controls should only take place if it is determined by root cause analysis to be necessary to solve the problem.
justification.C: Assessing the root cause is the first step in understanding whether control objectives and controls are inadequate or if some other cause must be addressed.
justification.D: Repeating the control test does not provide a root cause of the compromise that occurred.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important element to ensure the success of a disaster recovery test at a vendor-provided hot site?

options.B: Network Internet Protocol addresses are predefined.
options.C: Equipment at the hot site is identical.

justification.A: Testing on weekends can be advantageous, but this is not the most important choice.
justification.B: Because vendor-provided hot sites are in a state of constant change, it is not always possible to have network addresses defined in advance.
justification.C: Although it would be ideal to provide for identical equipment at the hot site, it is not always practical because multiple customers must be served and equipment specifications will vary.
justification.D: Disaster recovery testing requires the allocation of sufficient resources to be successful. Without the support of management, these resources will not be available, and testing will suffer as a result.

question: At the conclusion of a disaster recovery test, which of the following should ALWAYS be performed prior to leaving the vendor's hot site facility?

options.A: Erase data and software from devices.
options.B: Conduct a meeting to evaluate the test.
options.C: Complete an assessment of the hot site provider.
options.D: Evaluate the results from all test scripts.

justification.A: For security and privacy reasons, all organizational data and software should be erased prior to departure.
justification.B: Evaluations can occur back at the office after everyone is rested.
justification.C: An assessment of the hot site provider should be included in the postmortem.
justification.D: Results of the test are a part of the postmortem.

question: Which of the following is a key component of an incident response policy?

justification.A: Call trees are too detailed, change too frequently and are not a part of policy.
justification.B: Escalation criteria, indicating the circumstances under which specific actions are to be undertaken, should be contained within an incident response policy.
justification.C: Press release templates are too detailed to be included in a policy document.
justification.D: Lists of critical backup files are too detailed to be included in a policy document.

question: How does a security information and event management solution MOST likely detect the existence of an advanced persistent threat in its infrastructure?

options.A: Through analysis of the network traffic history
options.B: Through stateful inspection of firewall packets

justification.A: Advanced persistent threat (APT) refers to stealthy attacks not easily discovered without detailed analysis of behavior and traffic flows. Security information and event management (SIEM) solutions analyze network traffic over long periods of time to identify variances in behavior that may reveal APTs.
justification.B: Stateful inspection is a function of some firewalls but is not part of a SIEM solution. A stateful inspection firewall keeps track of the destination Internet Protocol address of each packet that leaves the enterprise's internal network. Whenever the response to a packet is received, its record is referenced to ascertain and ensure that the incoming message is in response to the request that went out from the enterprise.
justification.C: Zero-day attacks are not APTs because they are unknown until they manifest for the first time and cannot be proactively detected by SIEM solutions.
justification.D: A vulnerability assessment identifies areas that may potentially be exploited, but does not detect attempts at exploitation, so it is not related to APT.

question: Why should an incident management team conduct a post-incident review?

justification.A: Evaluating the relevance of evidence is not the primary purpose for a post-incident review because it should have been established during the response to the incident.
justification.B: Post-incident reviews are beneficial in determining ways to improve the response process through lessons learned from the attack.
justification.C: Identifying who launched the attack is not the primary purpose for a post-incident review because it should have been established during the response to the incident.
justification.D: Identifying what areas were affected is not the primary purpose for a post-incident review because it should have been established during the response to the incident.

question: What is the MOST important concern when an enterprise with multiple data centers designates one of its own facilities as the recovery site?

options.A: Communication line capacity between data centers
options.B: Current processing capacity loads at data centers
options.C: Differences in logical security at each center
options.D: Synchronization of system software release versions

justification.A: Although line capacity is important from a mirroring perspective, it is secondary to having the necessary capacity to restore critical systems.
justification.B: If data centers are operating at or near capacity, it may prove difficult to recover critical operations at an alternate data center.
justification.C: Differences in logical security constitute a much easier issue to overcome and are, therefore, of less concern.
justification.D: Synchronization of system software releases is a much easier issue to overcome and is, therefore, of less concern.

question: Which of the following is MOST important in determining whether a disaster recovery test is successful?

options.A: Only business data files from offsite storage are used.
options.B: IT staff fully recovers the processing infrastructure.
options.D: All systems are restored within recovery time objectives.

justification.A: Although ensuring that only materials taken from offsite storage are used in the test is important, it is not as critical in determining a test's success.
justification.B: While full recovery of the processing infrastructure is a key recovery milestone, it does not ensure the success of a test.
justification.C: To ensure that a disaster recovery test is successful, it is most important to determine whether all critical business functions were successfully recovered and duplicated.
justification.D: Achieving recovery time objectives is an important milestone, but it does not necessarily prove that the critical business functions can be conducted, due to interdependencies with other applications and key elements such as data, staff, manual processes, materials and accessories, etc.

question: Which of the following is MOST important when deciding whether to build an alternate facility or to subscribe to a third-party hot site?

options.A: Location of a redundant processing facility and cost to build it
options.B: Daily cost of losing critical systems and recovery time objectives
options.D: Criticality results from the business impact analysis

justification.A: Location is critical since the recovery site must not be subject to the same disaster as the primary site; cost is the second main consideration.
justification.B: The cost of losing critical systems is not affected by a buy-or-build choice.
justification.C: Infrastructure complexity and system sensitivity are the same whether in a third-party facility or not.
justification.D: Criticality is the same regardless of the alternate site choice.

question: A new email virus that uses an attachment disguised as a picture file is spreading rapidly over the Internet. Which of the following should be performed FIRST in response to this threat?

options.A: Quarantine all picture files stored on file servers.
options.B: Block all emails containing picture file attachments.
options.C: Quarantine all mail servers connected to the Internet.
options.D: Block incoming Internet mail but permit outgoing mail.

justification.A: There is no indication of infection and quarantining all picture files is unnecessary.
justification.B: Until signature files can be updated, incoming email containing picture file attachments should be blocked.
justification.C: Quarantine of all mail servers is unnecessary because only those emails containing attached picture files are in question.
justification.D: Blocking all incoming mail is unnecessary as long as picture files are blocked.

question: When a large enterprise discovers that it is the subject of a network probe, which of the following actions should be taken?

options.A: Reboot the router connecting the demilitarized zone (DMZ) to the firewall.
options.B: Power down all servers located on the DMZ segment.
options.C: Monitor the probe and isolate the affected segment.
options.D: Enable server trace logging on the affected segment.

justification.A: Rebooting the router is not warranted.
justification.B: Powering down the demilitarized zone servers is not warranted.
justification.C: In the case of a probe, the situation should be monitored and the affected network segment isolated.
justification.D: Enabling server trace routing is not warranted.

question: An enterprise determined that if its email system failed for three days, the cost to the enterprise would be eight times greater than if it could be recovered in one day. This determination MOST likely was the result of:

justification.A: A disaster recovery plan does not include impact of system loss. A business impact analysis must be completed prior to disaster recovery planning.
justification.B: A business impact analysis is used to establish the escalation of loss over time, in addition to other elements.
justification.C: Site proximity is a consideration during disaster recovery planning for locating a recovery site. Where the site is located does not indicate the business impact.
justification.D: Full interruption testing is used to validate disaster recovery plans. A business impact analysis must be completed prior to disaster recovery planning.

question: Which of the following should be performed FIRST in the aftermath of a denial-of-service (DoS) attack?

options.A: Restore servers from backup media stored offsite.
options.B: Conduct an assessment to determine system status.
options.C: Perform an impact analysis of the outage.

justification.A: Servers may not have been affected, so it is not necessary at this point to rebuild any servers.
justification.B: An assessment should be conducted to determine the overall system status and whether any permanent damage occurred.
justification.C: An impact analysis of the outage will not provide any immediate benefit.
justification.D: Isolating the screened subnet is after the fact and will not provide any benefit.

question: Which of the following is the MOST important element to ensure the successful recovery of a business during a disaster?

options.A: Detailed technical recovery plans are maintained offsite.
options.B: Network redundancy is maintained through separate providers.
options.C: Hot site equipment needs are recertified on a regular basis.
options.D: Appropriate declaration criteria have been established.

justification.A: In a major disaster, staff can be injured or can be prevented from traveling to the hot site, so technical skills and business knowledge can be lost. It is, therefore, critical to maintain an updated copy of the detailed recovery plan at an offsite location. In a disaster situation, without the detailed technical plan, business recovery will be seriously impaired.
justification.B: Continuity of the business requires adequate network redundancy. Ideally, the business continuity program addresses this satisfactorily.
justification.C: Continuity of the business requires hot site infrastructure that is certified as compatible, along with clear criteria. Ideally, the business continuity program addresses these needs satisfactorily.
justification.D: Continuity of the business requires clear criteria for declaring a disaster. Ideally, the business continuity program addresses this satisfactorily.

question: Addressing the root cause of an incident is one aspect of which of the following incident management processes?

justification.A: Determining the root cause of an incident and eliminating it are key activities that occur as part of the eradication process.
justification.B: Recovery focuses on restoring systems or services to conditions specified in service delivery objectives (SDOs) or business continuity plans (BCPs).
justification.C: Lessons learned are documented at the end of the incident response process, after the root cause has been identified and remediated.
justification.D: Containment focuses on preventing the spread of damage associated with an incident, typically while the root cause either is still unknown or is known but cannot yet be remediated.

question: An information security manager is investigating an internal cybersecurity incident and has been directed to preserve potential evidence. After creating an image copy of the hard drive of suspected systems with a commonly used tool and making copies on which to perform analysis, which of the following should the information security manager do NEXT?

options.A: Encrypt the primary and backup hard drive images.
options.B: Use an alternative tool to make an image copy of the hard drive.
options.C: Generate hashes for the primary and backup hard drive images.
options.D: Document the process used to make an image copy of the hard drive.

justification.A: Ensuring the confidentiality of the memory dumps is not a primary concern during forensic analysis. Encrypted memory dumps cannot be analyzed.
justification.B: If a memory dump made with an alternative tool is desired, it should be made only after the existing primary and backup dumps have been hashed, so that their authenticity can be established if necessary.
justification.C: Generating hashes for the primary and backup memory dumps provides a means of demonstrating that the dump used for analysis is identical to the one stored for reference. It is essential that this step be performed before anything might happen to corrupt the original memory source, so it should be done as soon as possible.
justification.D: Documentation of the process should exist as part of the incident response procedures, but if it does not, the middle of an incident is not the best time to create it.

question: When an enterprise is using an automated tool to manage and house its business continuity plans, which of the following is the PRIMARY concern?

options.A: Ensuring accessibility should a disaster occur
options.B: Versioning control as plans are modified
options.C: Broken hyperlinks to resources stored elsewhere
options.D: Tracking changes in personnel and plan assets

justification.A: If all the plans exist only in electronic form, this presents a serious weakness, as the electronic version may be dependent on restoration of the intranet or other systems that are no longer available.
justification.B: Versioning control is actually easier with an automated system.
justification.C: Broken hyperlinks are a concern, but less serious than plan accessibility.
justification.D: Tracking changes in personnel and plan assets is actually easier with an automated system.

question: The information security manager identifies a vulnerability in a publicly exposed business application during risk assessment activities. The NEXT step to take is:

justification.A: Containment is necessary when an incident is found to have occurred. Prior to analysis, the information security manager has no way of knowing whether an incident may have occurred in the past or might even still be underway, so analysis should precede containment.
justification.B: Eradication is undertaken once an incident has been contained, which requires that it first be analyzed to determine its scope.
justification.C: Identification of a vulnerability does not necessarily mean that an incident has occurred, but reliance on automated detection mechanisms when a vulnerability has been identified may allow any compromises that have already occurred to continue unimpeded. Analysis is appropriate to determine whether a threat actor may have already exploited the vulnerability and, if so, to determine the scope of the compromise.
justification.D: Recovery is the last step taken before concluding an incident. At the time that a vulnerability is detected, there is no apparent impact, so recovery is not yet needed. Eradication and recovery will take place if an incident has occurred. However, it is important to first determine if an incident has taken place.

question: Which of the following actions should be taken when an information security manager discovers that a hacker is footprinting the network perimeter?

options.A: Reboot the border router connected to the firewall.
options.B: Check intrusion detection system logs and monitor for any active attacks.
options.C: Update IDS software to the latest available version.
options.D: Enable server trace routing on the demilitarized zone segment.

justification.A: Rebooting the router would not be relevant.
justification.B: Information security should check the intrusion detection system (IDS) logs and continue to monitor the situation. It would be inappropriate to take any action beyond that.
justification.C: Updating the IDS could create a temporary exposure until the new version can be properly tuned.
justification.D: Enabling server trace routing is of no use.

question: The triage phase of the incident response plan provides:

options.A: a snapshot of the current status of all incident activity reported.
options.B: a global, high-level view of the open incidents.
options.C: a tactical review of an incident's progression and resolution.
options.D: a comprehensive basis for changes to the enterprise architecture.

justification.A: Triage gives a snapshot based on both strategic and tactical reviews for the purposes of assigning limited resources to where they can be most effective.
justification.B: Triage addresses the tactical level of the incident to be able to determine the best path to resolution and does not focus exclusively on the high-level view.
justification.C: Triage provides a view of both the tactical and strategic levels and occurs prior to resolution.
justification.D: Triage occurs before root-cause analysis, so it does not provide a comprehensive basis for changes to the enterprise architecture.

question: Which of the following is the MOST serious exposure of automatically updating virus signature files on every desktop each Friday at 11:00 p.m. (2300 hours)?

options.A: Most new viruses' signatures are identified over weekends.
options.B: Technical personnel are not available to support the operation.
options.C: Systems are vulnerable to new viruses during the intervening week.
options.D: The update's success or failure is not known until Monday.

justification.A: The fact that most new viruses' signatures are identified over weekends is secondary to leaving systems vulnerable during the intervening week.
justification.B: The fact that technical personnel are not available is secondary to leaving systems vulnerable during the intervening week.
justification.C: Updating virus signature files on a weekly basis carries the risk that the systems will be vulnerable to viruses released during the week; far more frequent updating is essential.
justification.D: The fact that success or failure is not known until Monday is secondary to leaving systems vulnerable during the intervening week.

question: When performing a business impact analysis, which of the following should calculate the recovery time and cost estimates?

justification.A: The business continuity coordinator will not be able to provide the correct level of detailed knowledge.
justification.B: The information security manager will not have the level of detailed knowledge needed.
justification.C: Business process owners are in the best position to understand the true impact on the business that a system outage would create.
justification.D: IT management would not be able to provide the required level of detailed knowledge.

question: Which of the following is MOST closely associated with a business continuity program?

options.A: Confirming that detailed technical recovery plans exist
options.C: Updating the hot site equipment configuration every quarter
options.D: Developing recovery time objectives for critical functions

justification.A: Technical recovery plans are associated with infrastructure disaster recovery.
justification.B: Network redundancy is associated with infrastructure disaster recovery.
justification.C: Equipment needs are associated with infrastructure disaster recovery.
justification.D: Of the choices, only recovery time objectives directly relate to business continuity.

question: An enterprise has just experienced a major incident that has caused interruption to critical business processes. What is the PRIMARY reason to conduct a post-incident review?

options.A: To identify responsible parties and apply disciplinary action or reward as appropriate
options.B: To document the event and ensure that all steps taken and issues encountered are listed
options.C: To ensure that all damage that resulted from the crisis is being fixed and that systems are stable
options.D: To determine the root cause of the crisis and take steps to prevent reoccurrence

justification.A: The post-incident review should address any training needs and personnel that played a role in the event, but this is not the primary objective.
justification.B: Documenting the event should have been conducted during the incident. The post-incident review will rely on the documentation to learn what happened and the chronology of events.
justification.C: It is important to ensure that all damage has been fixed, but this should have been done before the post-incident review.
justification.D: During the incident, efforts may have been focused on getting the business back up and running; the post-incident review should ensure that the root cause of the incident is identified and addressed.

question: A computer incident response team manual should PRIMARILY contain which of the following documents?

justification.A: Risk assessment results are a document that would not likely be included in a computer incident response team (CIRT) manual.
justification.B: Quickly ranking the severity criteria of an incident is a key element of incident response.
justification.C: The emergency call tree directory is a document that would not likely be included in a CIRT manual.
justification.D: A table of critical backup files is a document that would not likely be included in a CIRT manual.
